Job Description:
Summary
The Undergraduate Research Assistant will investigate morphological changes in a Drosophila neural circuit linked to alcohol preference. They will independently manage fly stocks, conduct immunohistochemistry experiments, and update experimental protocols. They will also utilize confocal microscopy and Amira software to rigorously quantify morphological parameters for data analysis. Finally, they will provide support and mentorship to other lab members, contributing to troubleshooting and experimental design.

View Job Posting Details
Community Dialogue Coordinator (Graduate Student)
Community Dialogue Coordinator (Graduate Student)
Apply
Job Description:
The Community Dialogue Project (CDP) advances student learning, inclusive community, and open inquiry on a university-wide basis through collaborations, programs, and services that support the development and use of skills for effective communication, dialogue, conflict resolution, and multipartial facilitation within the Brown University community. 
Community Dialogue Coordinators are Brown graduate students who take a leadership and coordination role within CDP, providing additional support, coaching, direction, and feedback to undergraduate facilitators.
Reporting to the Director for the Community Dialogue Project, the Community Dialogue Coordinators are  responsible for assisting with the continued development, implementation, and evaluation of CDP initiatives in order to support fellow students in the development of skills and strategies for communicating effectively, responding to conflict, engaging in interactional diversity, and pursuing mutual understanding of issues that affect the Brown community. 
 Section 3: Major Responsibilities
 1. Major Responsibility: Provide guidance and coaching to CDP facilitators, participate and lead required training and skill building activities. (30%)  
Develop agendas and materials for required trainings and meetings. 
Provide one-on-one coaching for CDP facilitators and support them in setting and achieving professional development and programmatic goals.
Establish, define, and measure progress towards facilitator sub-team objectives each semester.
Gain skills in effective facilitation and communication, building community, navigating and addressing issues related to power and privilege, organizational management, conflict resolution, and developing an inclusive culture.
Community Dialogue Facilitators are not confidential resources; Facilitators are responsible for adhering to FERPA policies and guidelines. 
If made aware of a direct threat of harm, Community Dialogue Facilitators must immediately share all relevant information with their supervisor and/or others, as appropriate (e.g., Administrator on Call, Brown Emergency Medical Services, Department of Public Safety).
Other duties as assigned and as determined as the position evolves.
2. Major Responsibility: Lead and develop training and skill development opportunities to students across campus on topics relevant to the Community Dialogue Project. (30%)
Community Dialogue Coordinators lead education and skill building for members of the Brown community to engage productively in difficult discussions and relationship building around conflicts and challenging topics. CDP grounds this work in principles and practices of social justice and equity in order to equip and enable participants to navigate and engage constructively in affirming, empowering, and community-building ways. 
Supporting Actions:
Help Director develop, design, and refine workshops and trainings on topics such as effective communication, active listening, perspective taking, and difficult conversations. 
Deliver workshops and trainings on topics such as effective communication, conflict resolution and transformation, mediation, and multipartial dialogue facilitation. 
Assist in planning and implementation of programs. 
3. Major Responsibility: Provide direct services such as conflict coaching and dialogue facilitation (20%)
Community Dialogue Coordinators, with supervision and support from professional staff, will work with peers to help equip and support students in navigating and engaging constructively in challenging conflicts and difficult conversations in affirming, socially-conscious, community-building ways. This will take the form of working with individuals and groups to plan and engage in dialogue and directly supporting dialogue when requested. Coordinators will support Facilitators to conduct intakes, develop custom programming, and deliver high-quality dialogue, facilitation, and conflict coaching services. 
Supporting Actions:
Serve as a resource to Community Coordinators (CCs), student group leaders, student athletes, program leaders and others who want to initiate dialogue on particular issues or topics. 
Help peers plan dialogue sessions including framing, invitations, mode of facilitation, prompting questions and so on. Provide dialogue facilitation for groups, teams, or communities when requested. 
Coach peers interested in addressing conflicts without the assistance of an external facilitator. Assist in identifying conflict management strategies relevant to their situation. Help peers develop strategies for responding to conflict in the future.
Respond to student requests around specific incidents or conflicts and plan facilitation interventions. 
Plan dialogue sessions around issues that Community Dialogue Facilitators view as pertinent to the campus community. Facilitators will work in teams of two or three to design and implement facilitations for the campus at-large or individual communities from across the university. 

 4. Major Responsibility: Promote CDP programs and initiatives by helping to recruit, train, and advise students to serve as Community Dialogue Facilitators and raising awareness of CDP offerings. (20%)  
Community Dialogue Coordinators are essential ambassadors and help lead outreach for the work of the Community Dialogue Project. 
Supporting Actions:
Contribute to development of CDP communications materials and provide oversight and guidance to undergraduate facilitators outreach programming. 
Seek out opportunities and collaborate with student organizations and other departments to build partnerships, 
Serve as a resource to members of the campus community, including students and administrators, and consult with those interested in engaging in meaningful dialogue. 
Help promote recruitment and onboarding of other Community Dialogue Facilitators. 
Section 4: Time Commitment
Average of 6-10 hours per week, with some fluctuation.
Attendance at CDP facilitator orientation workshops and winter refresher training, typically two paid full days. Dates TBD.

 Section 5: Job Qualifications and Remuneration
Job Qualifications
Desire to develop skills to be an effective facilitator and mediator, and support community well-being through dialogue. Previous experience with in-person or online facilitation or other dialogue-based programs is not required.
Experience and commitment to leading and supporting undergraduate students in their development as new facilitators and peacebuilding professionals.
Possess a strong interest in social justice and a desire to affect change in how students build community and navigate conflict,
Capacity to deal with sensitive and potentially divisive topics in a conciliatory, sensitive, and inclusive manner.
Capacity for humility, patience, confidence, passion, and empathy. 
Desire to improve oral and written communication skills; ability to communicate effectively with peers, and University employees. 
Understanding of issues related to equity, inclusion, education, active learning, discrimination, intersectionality, mental health, ability, feminism, class, Indigenous histories and realities, decolonization, LGBTQIA+ issues, anti-racism, ethnicity, sexual violence awareness and prevention, facilitation, social work, sociology, political science, psychology, is preferred. 
Must have the ability to work independently as well as in partnership with a team. Coordinators can expect to work up to 10 hours a week with some fluctuation. Summer hours may also be available if the Coordinator has availability and interest. 
Remuneration
$17/hr (students are paid for required trainings and meetings).
Questions? Please contact anthony_medeiros@brown.edu

Doctoring Senior Substitute
Doctoring Senior Substitute
Apply
Job Description:
What is a "Doctoring Senior Sub"?

In the event that one of our regular faculty is unable to attend an afternoon Doctoring session, Doctoring Senior Subs are asked to co-teach a group of first- or second-year students with either an MD or SBS co-teacher.  Small groups occur for Doctoring Year 1 on Tuesday afternoon and Year 2 on Thursday afternoon. Senior Subs fill in for either the MD or SBS role and provide hands-on teaching for the clinical skills taught in the Doctoring Program including medical interviewing, physical diagnosis, oral presentations, written documentation, advanced communication, and professionalism.  Expectations for the role include:
Prepare for the session by reviewing faculty guides which are made available when you sign-up for a specific session;
Attend the Doctoring sessions you have signed-up for and coordinate with your co-teacher on the plan for the day; 
Communicate any student-related concerns that arise during the session to the small group faculty and/or course leaders
Where would I need to be and when?
Classes are held at the Medical School in the lecture halls, seminar rooms, and the Clinical Skills Suite on either a Tuesday or Thursday from 1-4pm, August through May Scheduling for days that need to be covered is organized using a Google calendar. Scheduling is typically done on a first-come, first-served basis. 

What are the benefits of being a "Doctoring Senior Sub"?
Parking accommodations are provided at The Warren Alpert Medical School at Brown University on teaching days.  Students are paid per session bi-monthly in Workday.

Fall 2025 BIOL2230 Supplemental Teaching Assistant
Fall 2025 BIOL2230 Supplemental Teaching Assistant

Job Description:
Biology Supplemental Teaching Assistants (STAs) are graduate level teaching assistants who support course instructors with tasks that may include the following:
Leading discussion sessions or labs
Holding office hours and/or review sessions
Providing feedback and academic support to enrolled students
Overseeing/performing administrative tasks
Grading
Posting grades to Canvas
Canvas communications monitoring and support
Qualifications
Candidate must be a currently enrolled Brown University graduate student in good academic standing
Candidate must have successfully completed the course they are applying to (or demonstrate evidence of other course enrollments that are equivalent in content knowledge)
Candidate must conduct themselves in a professional and ethical manner
Candidate must maintain confidentiality per University standards
Candidate must demonstrate effective communication skills
Candidate must complete I-9 process prior to first day of work
Candidate must be domestic-based in order to qualify for the TA opportunity during Fall 2025 semester
More specifically
The master's level teaching assistant for BIOL 2230/40 (BME and Biotechnology Seminar) supports the course in three main areas: 
Course organization, management of Panopto
Zoom presentations and recordings 
Management of speaker feedback
Compensation for the fall semester will be at the amount approved by the Division of Biology and Medicine. Assuming acceptable performance of duties, the TA may be given the option to continue as TA for the spring semester. Applicants should be a ScM student in either the Biomedical Engineering or Biotechnology Graduate Programs. Preferential consideration will be given to students in their second year of the program. Chosen STAs must maintain regular communication with the course instructor for the full semester and perform duties as requested in a timely manner.

Fall 2025 Biology Undergraduate Teaching Assistant

Job Description:
Biology Undergraduate Teaching Assistants (UTAs) support course instructors with tasks that may include the following:
Leading discussion sessions or labs
Holding office hours and/or review sessions
Providing feedback and academic support to enrolled students
Overseeing/performing administrative tasks
Grading with supervision from the instructor
Course communications monitoring and support
Qualifications
Candidate must be a currently enrolled Brown University undergraduate student in good academic standing
Candidate must have successfully completed the course they are applying to (or demonstrate evidence of other course enrollments that are equivalent in content knowledge)
Candidate must conduct themselves in a professional and ethical manner
Candidate must maintain confidentiality per University standards
Candidate must demonstrate effective communication skills
Candidate must complete I-9 process prior to first day of work
Candidate must be domestic-based in order to qualify for the TA opportunity during Fall 2025 semester
Learning Objectives
Critically reflect on their teaching practices and any biases to support and engage all students in the learning process;
Collaborate with instructors on improving course learning goals and creating equitable teaching and learning environments by giving and receiving critical course feedback;
Create a community of learners across course TAs, students, and instructors;
Identify and effectively communicate key concepts in their respective course(s) with students;
Develop professional skills such as problem solving, critical thinking, ethical conduct, mentorship, and time management;
Effectively engage with course concepts to enhance their own learning;
Incorporate teaching and disciplinary skills to their everyday lives.

Chosen UTAs must keep regular communication with the course instructor for the full semester and perform duties as requested in a timely manner. Position hours are to be determined and the pay structure is as follows:
Undergraduates who TA the same BIOL course for the second (or more) time receive $20.49/hr.
Undergraduates with prior experience as a BIOL course UTA, but in a different course receive $18.83/hr.
Undergraduates who TA a BIOL course for the first time receive $18.00/hr.

Student Research Assistant
Student Research Assistant
Apply
Job Description:
Job Overview:
We are seeking a research assistant to work on projects related to young adult bystander behavior to prevent risk in situations involving alcohol use. RAs will work with a Project Coordinator and small team of undergraduate RAs on tasks related to data collection with participants in person, and on monitoring participant progress. Work will happen on NIH-funded research projects in the Center for Alcohol and Addiction Studies in the School of Public Health with a vibrant and engaged group of staff and faculty.
Primary Responsibilities:
• Participant recruitment: RA will oversee recruitment of young adult drinkers from the community. This will involve posting advertisements, corresponding with interested participants, managing screening for eligibility, and scheduling participants. • Data collection: RA will train participants in the completion of Qualtrics and MetricWire (Daily Diary and Ecological momentary assessment (EMA)) data collection in accordance with standardized research protocol and guide participants through informed consent.
• Participant follow-up. Track participants during EMA portion using detailed logs; correspond with participants regarding compliance; schedule participants for follow-up appointments, conduct follow-up appointments.
• Assist with other study-related tasks as needed.
Requirements:
● Excellent organizational and communication skills.
● Ability to work both independently and in a team is required.
● Flexibility in work schedule is preferable, including evening hours and possible weekends
● College-level coursework in Psychology, Public Health, or related field with at least 1-year experience in a research lab or equivalent environment preferred.
● Previous research experience through academic training or previous work experience preferred.
● Knowledge of computer applications, including Word, PowerPoint and Excel

2025-08-13

Job Description:
TASK DESCRIPTION:
Performs a variety of tasks primarily related to the preparation, service, support, supply and sanitation functions in a food service environment. Typical tasks may include some or all of the following, but are not limited to:
  1. Friendly, efficient service and presentation of food to customers.
  2. Answer questions related to foods (and ingredients) served.
  3. Maintain a neat and orderly service area.
  4. Restock food and supplies as requested.
  5. Assist with preparation and service for special functions, buffets, etc.
  6. Remove trash and dispose of in proper containers.
  7. Maintain a neat, well-groomed appearance.
  8. Clean and sanitize work area, tables, chairs, pots and pans, utensils and equipment.
  9. Work independently and with other staff
10. Perform other tasks, including cashier/check or other duties, as requested.
POSITION QUALIFICATIONS:
- Positive and friendly customer relations skills.
- Ability to understand and follow instructions.
- Basic math ability relating to portion control, counting, restocking, and cashier/checker duties.
- High manual dexterity (quickness, accuracy and safety).
- Ability to complete tasks quickly, thoroughly and safely.
- Ability to handle complex duties, anticipate needs and juggle multiple tasks where priorities have been pre-established.
- Ability to operate assigned equipment correctly and safely.
- Ability to lift goods or equipment weighing up to 50 pounds.
- Ability to stand for extended period of time
- Possesses a willingness and ability to support and promote a diverse and inclusive campus community

Dining Services Student Worker

Job Description:
TASK DESCRIPTION:
Performs a variety of tasks primarily related to the preparation, service, support, supply and sanitation functions in a food service environment. Typical tasks may include some or all of the following, but are not limited to:
  1. Friendly, efficient service and presentation of food to customers.
  2. Answer questions related to foods (and ingredients) served.
  3. Maintain a neat and orderly service area.
  4. Restock food and supplies as requested.
  5. Assist with preparation and service for special functions, buffets, etc.
  6. Remove trash and dispose of in proper containers.
  7. Maintain a neat, well-groomed appearance.
  8. Clean and sanitize work area, tables, chairs, pots and pans, utensils and equipment.
  9. Work independently and with other staff
10. Perform other tasks, including cashier/check or other duties, as requested.
POSITION QUALIFICATIONS:
- Positive and friendly customer relations skills.
- Ability to understand and follow instructions.
- Basic math ability relating to portion control, counting, restocking, and cashier/checker duties.
- High manual dexterity (quickness, accuracy and safety).
- Ability to complete tasks quickly, thoroughly and safely.
- Ability to handle complex duties, anticipate needs and juggle multiple tasks where priorities have been pre-established.
- Ability to operate assigned equipment correctly and safely.
- Ability to lift goods or equipment weighing up to 50 pounds.
- Ability to stand for extended period of time
- Possesses a willingness and ability to support and promote a diverse and inclusive campus community

ArtsCrew Student Worker
ArtsCrew Student Worker
Apply
Job Description:
Established in 2021, Brown Arts Institute (BAI) is a university-wide research enterprise and catalyst for the arts at Brown that creates new work and supports, amplifies, and adds new dimensions to the creative practices of Brown’s arts departments, faculty, students, and community. Through year-round programming, research-focused courses, initiatives, collaborations, and partnerships, along with rigorous artistic and academic programs, BAI commissions and presents new work on campus, across Providence, Rhode Island, and beyond, from students, faculty, and on-campus arts groups, as well as in collaboration with forward-focused visiting artists and other performing arts organizations.
Working within The Lindemann Performing Arts Center, The Granoff Center for the Creative Arts, and The Bell Gallery, the BAI aims to fulfill Brown’s ambitious vision for the arts as an integral presence throughout a liberal arts education. We believe the arts are fundamental to critical inquiry into the most pressing questions facing humanity worldwide, and we support artists operating at the highest levels of their craft to inform and be informed by scholars in disciplines across the sciences, social sciences, and humanities.
ArtsCrew Members are a key component of The BAI’s operations and the larger arts and culture ecosystem throughout Brown University and Rhode Island at large. Members assist in planning, executing, and evaluating programs and events while learning hands-on skills in several areas of arts work. Members are assigned to a team within the BAI based on their skills and interests, but they may be cross-trained and fill several roles as assistants throughout the BAI’s operations, including:
Creative Technologies: 2D/3D printers, equipment, podcasting, recording studio, etc.
Exhibitions: gallery monitors and tour guides, preparators, public art tour guides, etc.
Marketing & Communications: content creation, copywriters, graphic designers, photographers, videographers, etc.
Production: audio, carpentry, lighting, stage management, stagehands, video, etc.
Programming: administration, artist services, company management, hospitality, etc.
Visitor Services: house management, box office, tour guides, ushers, etc.
Other administrative tasks as assigned.
Some roles require a series of paid skills training before filling shifts in one or more focus areas. ArtsCrew offers flexible scheduling, averaging 5-15 hours per week, depending on operational needs and individual availability. Most work occurs in BAI venues; however, there are occasional opportunities for members to work throughout Brown University’s campus as assigned and on projects off-campus with BAI’s partner organizations.
We ask that applicants be willing to serve as ushers for events as needed. Employees in Production or Preparator shifts must be able to lift 40 pounds. All positions may require employees to stand for extended periods.
Competencies:
Please note: Applicants are not expected to meet every competency listed below, as some are specific to certain roles within ArtsCrew. We encourage individuals with a strong interest in learning and contributing to the arts to apply.
Effective Communication and Collaborative Spirit: Demonstrates clear and respectful communication skills and a strong willingness to collaborate with diverse teams, including artists, staff, and other stakeholders.
Interest in and Foundational Understanding of Arts Operations: Exhibits a genuine interest in learning about the operational and logistical aspects of live events and/or visual art galleries. Prior familiarity is a plus, but not required.
Eagerness to Engage in Event Support Roles: Shows enthusiasm for participating in various event support roles, such as visitor services, basic production assistance, or administrative tasks. Previous experience in these areas is valued.
Aptitude for Learning Technical Skills (Role-Dependent): Displays an aptitude and willingness to learn and utilize relevant technologies and systems, such as ticketing software or basic production equipment. Any existing technical skills are beneficial.
Commitment to Professional Development in the Arts (Role-Dependent): Demonstrates a commitment to learning about professional standards and best practices in their area(s) of interest within the arts (e.g., stagecraft, gallery operations, customer service).
Proactive Engagement and Attention to Detail: Exhibits a proactive attitude, a willingness to take initiative, and a commitment to accuracy and attention to detail in assigned tasks.
Applicants are asked to submit a resume.
Recruiting Start Date:
2025-08-14

Student Advocate for Health & Wellness - Computer Science
Student Advocate for Health & Wellness - Computer Science
Apply
Job Description:
Under the supervision and guidance of the Brown CS Inclusion and Outreach Program, the CS Health and Wellness Student Advocate works directly with students to provide individualized support around mental and physical health, accessibility, disability rights, and academic accommodations. The advocate acts as a peer resource, liaison, and changemaker within the department, helping build a more inclusive and supportive environment for all members of the CS community. 
This is a semester-based position; advocates must reapply and be rehired each term.
Key Responsibilities:
Student Support & Peer Resource:
Meet one-on-one with students to offer guidance, share resources, and connect them with relevant campus offices and supports based on the issues or pressures they are facing.
Serve as a peer resource and facilitator for conversations between students, faculty, and staff around topics such as mental and physical health, wellness, disability rights, and accessibility 
Response & Resolution:
Respond to student-reported concerns or instances of harm in a trauma-informed and student-centered manner.
Collaborate with students to develop resolution strategies that prioritize their agency and well-being.
Institutional Collaboration:
Work closely with the Brown CS Diversity Committee to identify, evaluate, and address systemic issues in the department related to wellness, accessibility, and disability inclusion.
Contribute to the ongoing development, implementation, and refinement of the Brown CS Diversity & Inclusion Action Plan (DDIAP).
Programming & Training:
Design and lead semesterly Accessibility Trainings and self-care workshops
Promote wellness, accessibility, and inclusive teaching practices across the department, including universal design principles and website accessibility.
Advocacy & Awareness:
Disseminate information about resources and raise awareness around health, wellness, accessibility, and disability rights through events, campaigns, and workshops.
Advocate for best practices in course design, departmental policies, and communication strategies to ensure greater access and inclusion.
Leadership & Engagement:
Become a member of the CS Diversity Committee and attend all monthly meetings (with faculty, staff, and graduate students) 
Attend all weekly student advocate cohort meetings.
Lead an academic year-long project that addresses a specific area related to the role’s responsibilities and aligns with the advocate’s personal interests.
Required Experience:
Completed and/or enrolled in at least 1 full academic year of Computer Science courses
Declared CS/joint-CS concentration
Preferred Experience (not required):
Facilitation and Mentorship
Leadership and Teamwork
Social Justice Advocacy 
Time Commitment:
~5 hours per week
Pay: $21.75 per hour
1-Semester: Start September 15 - December 15, 2025 
Recruiting Start Date:
2025-08-13

Student Advocate for Diversity & Inclusion - Computer Science
Student Advocate for Diversity & Inclusion - Computer Science
Apply
Job Description:
Under the supervision and guidance of the Brown CS Inclusion and Outreach Program, the Diversity and Inclusion (D&I) Student Advocate plays a vital role in advancing a more inclusive, equitable, and welcoming environment within the Brown University Computer Science Department. This student leadership position is designed for individuals passionate about social justice, equity, and advocacy, and offers an opportunity to directly influence departmental culture, programming, and policy. Advocates collaborate closely with faculty, staff, and students to promote belonging and address systemic barriers to access and representation in computer science.
Key Responsibilities:
(a) Program Development and Community Engagement
Develop and manage programs and initiatives aimed at:
Assessing departmental culture
Promoting inclusive communities
Improving students’ sense of belonging
Reducing structural and cultural barriers to access
Create and implement a personal project that aligns with your area of interest and contributes to these goals.
(b) Student Advocacy
Serve as a one-on-one advocate and peer resource for students navigating issues related to intersectional diversity, equity, and inclusion.
Offer support and referrals related to academic, social, and personal challenges.
(c) Committee Participation
Serve as a full member of the CS Diversity Committee, participating in monthly meetings with faculty, staff, and graduate students.
Contribute to the refinement, implementation, evaluation, and revision of the Brown CS Diversity & Inclusion Action Plan (DDIAP).
(d) Meeting Participation
Attend all Monthly CS Diversity Committee meetings (with faculty, staff, and graduate students)
Attend all weekly student advocate cohort meetings
Attend all Advocate events and trainings
(e) Training and Leadership
Design and lead semesterly Diversity & Inclusion Training sessions.
Collaborate with the Socially Responsible TA (STA) program to enhance content and promote inclusive practices within the TA community.
(f) Collaboration with Student Groups and Department Initiatives
Work alongside student organizations (e.g., Mosaic+, WiCS, Spectrum, Health & Wellness Advocates) to ensure diverse voices are heard and represented in department programming.
Required Experience:
Completed and/or enrolled in at least 1 full year of Computer Science courses
Declared CS/joint-CS concentration

Facilitation and Mentorship

Social Justice Advocacy

This position is best suited for someone with an interest in social media content and some background in video editing for social media. Experience with social media management preferred.

Aquatics - Lifeguard
Aquatics - Lifeguard
Apply
Job Description:
This position is responsible for ensuring the safety and well-being of the Katherine Moran Coleman Aquatics Center pool patrons (Brown students, faculty, staff, alumni, coaches, administrators, RISD students & faculty and general community members) by preventing and responding to emergencies.
All department employees are required to demonstrate exemplary ethical conduct and conformance to NCAA rules and regulations; the duties of the position are to be performed in compliance with all NCAA, Ivy League and ECAC rules and regulations; and any rules violations on behalf of themselves or any knowledge of violations within the department are to be reported to the appropriate parties.

Qualifications:
High School Diploma/GED.
Current certification in American Red Cross Lifeguard/First Aid/CPR for the Professional Rescuer, or equivalent.
Candidate must successfully demonstrate all the following swim and rescue skills as part of the interview process: Swim Test; Brick Test; Legs Only Tread; Rescue Skills Scenarios; Spinal Injury Management; CPR/AED/First Aid Scenarios.
Ability to act swiftly in emergency situations using aquatic rescue equipment.
Thorough knowledge and application of lifeguarding skills and rescue techniques to provide care for breathing and cardiac emergencies, injuries and sudden illnesses until Brown emergency services arrives.
Ability to make quick decisions and take decisive action.  Assertive in enforcing facility rules and regulations consistently in a professional and customer service-oriented manner.
Possess a willingness and ability to support a diverse and inclusive environment.
Leadership and public relations skills.
Must be responsible, alert, dependable and on time for scheduled shift.
Ability to work flexible hours, including evenings, weekends, holidays, school vacations and summers.
The successful candidate for this position will be required to complete a criminal background check satisfactory to Brown University prior to commencing employment.

Simmons Center Carceral State Reading Group Co-Facilitator
Simmons Center Carceral State Reading Group Co-Facilitator
Apply
Job Description:
Overview
The Simmons Center is looking to hire a creative, energetic, and experienced Co-Facilitator for the Carceral State Reading Group for the fall semester (with the potential to continue during the spring semester). The Simmons Center is a scholarly research center with a public humanities mission. Our work is focused on projects and research clusters that examine the history and legacies of the racial slave trade.
The Carceral State Reading Group is a collection or perhaps commons of Brown Students, formerly incarcerated organizers, practitioners, artists, and professors. The group is committed to serious study, intellectual vulnerability, and collaborative creation as they develop analyses around contemporary conditions of captivity and relationships/power to help us contest, and outlive these conditions. The group typically meets once per month during the school year for two hours around dinner and an assigned reading, film, poem, or piece.
Responsibilities
The activities of the undergraduate Carceral State Reading Group Co-Facilitator include organizing regular meetings of the Carceral State Reading Group, recruiting and communicating with Brown University and Providence community members interested in joining the group, reaching out to potential guest speakers and helping to coordinate logistics, communicating regularly with Simmons Center's staff about preparing for and planning events, meetings and group activities, and other related activities as assigned. The undergraduate Carceral State Reading Group Co-Facilitator must work collaboratively with the graduate co-facilitator in planning, preparing for, and running meetings and is responsible for all group members while they are at the Simmons Center.
Qualifications
Strong written and verbal communication skills, very organized and self-motivated, comfortable with Google Suite. Past experience participating in the Carceral State Reading Group and/or engagement with questions around the carceral state and mass incarceration is strongly preferred.
Additional information
The position is flexible in terms of hours and start date, but we would like the student to work between 5-10 hours weekly during the fall and spring semesters as needed, depending on the meeting schedule of the group.
This position is a student worker grade E with a starting salary of $16.00/hr. Please upload both a resume and cover letter along with your application.

Biology Supplemental Teaching Assistants (STAs) are graduate level teaching assistants who support course instructors with tasks that may include the following:

Overseeing/performing administrative tasks
Grading
Posting grades to Canvas
Canvas communications monitoring and support
Attend lectures as needed and run the Canvas page

Candidate must maintain confidentiality per University standards

Undergraduate Teaching Assistant (UTA) - Japanese Language Program
Undergraduate Teaching Assistant (UTA) - Japanese Language Program
Apply
Job Description:
1. Native speakers of Japanese or non-native Japanese speakers who are enthusiastic about assisting the Japanese language instruction. Native or very good pronunciation and strong conversational skills at the intermediate level are minimally required. For advanced-level classes (above JAPN500), the candidate must have completed JAPN0700 or above.
2. Able to work 1.5-3 hours per week. Work begins from the week of September 17th and ends in the week of Reading Period.
3. Please upload an updated CV (in English) and an essay (400-600 characters in Japanese) introducing yourself and why you believe you are a good fit for this position. If you have previously worked as a Japanese TA, write an essay to share your thoughts on your experience as a Japanese TA. Short-listed candidates will have an interview in Japanese.

Dining Services Student Worker

Job Description:
TASK DESCRIPTION:
Performs a variety of tasks primarily related to the preparation, service, support, supply and sanitation functions in a food service environment. Typical tasks may include some or all of the following, but are not limited to:
  1. Friendly, efficient service and presentation of food to customers.
  2. Answer questions related to foods (and ingredients) served.
  3. Maintain a neat and orderly service area.
  4. Restock food and supplies as requested.
  5. Assist with preparation and service for special functions, buffets, etc.
  6. Remove trash and dispose of in proper containers.
  7. Maintain a neat, well-groomed appearance.
  8. Clean and sanitize work area, tables, chairs, pots and pans, utensils and equipment.
  9. Work independently and with other staff
10. Perform other tasks, including cashier/check or other duties, as requested.
POSITION QUALIFICATIONS:
- Positive and friendly customer relations skills.
- Ability to understand and follow instructions.
- Basic math ability relating to portion control, counting, restocking, and cashier/checker duties.
- High manual dexterity (quickness, accuracy and safety).
- Ability to complete tasks quickly, thoroughly and safely.
- Ability to handle complex duties, anticipate needs and juggle multiple tasks where priorities have been pre-established.
- Ability to operate assigned equipment correctly and safely.
- Ability to lift goods or equipment weighing up to 50 pounds.
- Ability to stand for extended period of time
- Possesses a willingness and ability to support and promote a diverse and inclusive campus community

International and Public Affairs Student Assistant
International and Public Affairs Student Assistant
Apply
Job Description:
The International and Public Affairs (IAPA) undergraduate program is seeking a reliable and enthusiastic Student Assistant to support the daily operations of the academic program office at the Watson Institute. This role offers a great opportunity to develop administrative, communication, and leadership skills while contributing to the success of the IAPA concentration. The Student Assistant will work closely with the Undergraduate Concentrations Manager and Academic Program Coordinator and maintain regular office hours.
Key Responsibilities
Create, edit, and distribute the bi-weekly IAPA eNewsletter.
Enter and update student records in the IAPA database.
Organize and maintain hard-copy files for new concentrators.
Provide peer advising during scheduled office hours.
Serve as the first point of contact for visitors and phone calls to the Undergraduate Program suite.
Assist with planning and execution of events (e.g., Honors Conference, open houses, faculty lunches).
Serve as a liaison to the IAPA DUG and represent the program as a knowledgeable and engaged IAPA student.
Represent the program as a knowledgeable and engaged IAPA student.
Provide general office support, including:
Retrieving mail
Printing materials for courses and outreach events
Monitoring office supplies
Keeping the suite organized and information displays up to date
Greet students arriving for advising, review paperwork, and retrieve student files for the advisor.
Respond to inquiries in person, by phone, or via email, and direct questions to appropriate staff as needed.
Qualifications
Required:
Must be an IAPA concentrator.
Strong written and verbal communication skills.
Ability to handle inquiries with tact, professionalism, and accuracy.
Dependable, organized, and able to manage multiple tasks at once.
Proficient in Microsoft Word, Excel, Gmail, and Adobe Acrobat.
Cover letter is required.
 Preferred:
Familiarity with Microsoft Access, Photoshop, or web publishing tools.
Junior or senior standing is preferred, though all IAPA concentrators are welcome to apply.
Learning Goals & Professional Development
This role offers valuable hands-on experience in academic program administration, communications, and peer leadership. As a Student Assistant, you will:
Gain experience using web-based tools to develop and distribute a professional eNewsletter.
Build communication, writing, and customer service skills.
Learn how to support academic programming and student advising in a university setting.
Engage with faculty, staff, and fellow students to deepen your understanding of the IAPA concentration.
Represent IAPA through involvement with the DUG and program events.  
Practice reliability, accountability, multitasking, and attention to detail—skills applicable to any career path.

2025-05-13

Student Media Technician

Job Description:
Media Services is excited to hire Student Media Technicians (SMT)! SMTs provide audio-visual support for classes, meetings and events on campus and remotely via Zoom. Student Media Technicians learn all aspects of AV support and may be involved in assisting faculty in the classroom or supporting hybrid events.

Students who seek a position they can grow into will have the opportunity to support important campus events and to work independently during the evenings. We provide ongoing training for a wide range of audiovisual technologies, such as sound boards, lighting, Crestron control systems and more. As a member of the Media Services team, you will work on independent projects and also collaborate with fellow student workers and full-time staff. You will learn valuable troubleshooting skills, and interface with faculty, administrators, students and visiting speakers.

We will interview applicants as they apply. Applications from international students are welcome!

For the latest information about all Media Services job opportunities, visit:

CNTR Communications Coordinator
CNTR Communications Coordinator
Apply
Job Description:
Computer science and adjacent technologies have moved beyond infrastructure, touching all aspects of human life. Data driven systems can amplify and exacerbate existing inequities and power relationships within a society.  Computer science was never designed to address the problems of people, groups, or societies.  This gap widens as automated decision making has become an integral element in society, potentially affecting people’s rights, opportunities for advancement, and access to critical needs and services. 
 The Center for Technological Responsibility, Re-imagination, and Redesign (CNTR) guides the way on how to build technology that works—for all—by ensuring a focus not on what we build, but on the people we are building for.
The CNTR Communications Coordinator will manage and enhance the CNTR's internal and external communications, ensuring effective information flow to all stakeholders and promoting the organization's mission.  This role will especially focus on the best ways to reach and engage with students and faculty within the Brown community.
Major Job Duties:
Oversee and moderate the general CNTR Slack workspace, as well as specific channels
Organize and consolidate the friends and faculty database for improved outreach
Streamline and implement a new listserv system to ensure efficient communication
Potential to manage and create content for the CNTR newsletter, and develop promotional materials for events
Potential to create social media accounts (Instagram, BlueSky, LinkedIn, etc) for CNTR specifically 
Assist CNTR Program Manager in developing and executing a comprehensive communications strategy
Collaborate with DSI Communications & Events Coordinator as necessary to maintain overall alignment
Resources Provided:
Existing friends and faculty database
Access to newsletter and listserv platforms
Guidance and support from the Program Manager
Established communications templates and brand guidelines
 One grant-funded position is available for undergraduate students from any department or discipline within Brown University.  All positions are expected to work 5-10 hours per week at $20 per hour.

Teaching Assistant ENGN 0090
Teaching Assistant ENGN 0090
Apply
Job Description:
Job description:
We are seeking one hourly graduate student STA for undergraduate course ENGN 0090 (Fall).

About the course:
ENGN 90 is a seminal course at Brown for undergraduate students interested in the study of management and business. Initially offered in 1972 by Professor Barrett Hazeltine, this case-method based course has served as the introduction to business principles for tens of thousands of Brown students who have gone on to serve as CEO or found countless enterprises.

ENGN 90 (Management of Industrial and Nonprofit Organizations) offers an introduction to management study, spending 2-3 weeks each on fundamental concepts in Strategy, Marketing, Finance, Operations and Organization Behavior. These concepts apply to organizations of all sizes and types, from large, for-profit business to nonprofits to entrepreneurial ventures.

STA Responsibilities and Opportunities:
STAs have a variety of different ways in which to contribute to the courses. STAs will be assigned to roles based on their interests. Some responsibilities of past STAs include:
1) Working with Prof. Chaltas to identify an HBS case for final exam and write the final exam. This represents a deep dive into the case and working with Prof. Chaltas to write a final exam (and develop answer key) based on past finals (1 STA).
2) Managing Class Participation & Attendance (2 STAs): STAs attend class (T/Th 1-2:20PM AND 2:30-3:50PM and track student participation. They also track comments in Canvas discussions and track attendance taken via Tophat technology platform.
3) Developing List (including brief summary and key issues) of ~25 HBS cases from which students can write final papers. This list is used the next time we teach the course. This work is researching/reading many cases quickly to identify those appropriate to final papers. (2 STAs)
4) Final Exams: All STAs will grade one question between exam period and the Christmas holiday

Students will likely work less than 5 hours per week during the semester, but the final exam grading takes place after final exams and before Christmas and does take some time. 
Position Qualifications:
Knowledge of management principles (strategy, finance, marketing, operations, organization behavior). Experience with case method teaching. Experience as a TA preferred. 
Recruiting Start Date:
2025-08-06

Swearer Center Communications Student Worker
Swearer Center Communications Student Worker
Apply
Job Description:
This undergraduate student worker role provides event coverage, writing, and photography support for the Swearer Center communications team. This role is intended to ensure consistent, up-to-date content creation for events and special projects, including but not limited to writing post-event coverage, interviews, and photography. The position may offer additional support to the communications team.
Learning Opportunities
Working closely with the communications team, the student worker will:
Gain experience in communications planning and project management;
Collaborate with staff at the Swearer Center;
Gain exposure to a professional office setting and career paths in communications, academic administration, and applied research.
Qualifications
Comfortable with media creation and storytelling;
Familiarity with Canva and/or Adobe Creative Cloud, Photoshop;
A commitment to social justice and an interest in integrating the work of the University with work in the community;
Strong detail orientation; self-motivated; demonstrated ability to work independently;
An interest in engaging with diverse stakeholders;
Excellent written and oral communication skills;
Basic administrative skills.
Requirements
The position will begin in the fall and end in May 2026 (except for university holidays and breaks) with a possibility for an extension. This role is expected to take around 10 hours per week and pays $15.00 per hour.
Apply
Please include a resume and a cover letter describing your relevant experience and familiarity with the platforms above. Applications will be reviewed on a rolling basis with a priority deadline of September 5th.
If you have questions about the position, please contact Jessica Pontarelli Evans, Swearer Center Assistant Director of Communications, at jessica_pontarelli@brown.edu.

Music Office Assistant--Photographer / Social Media Assistant

Job Description:
Photographer/ Social Media Assistant
Under the direction of the Department Manager and the Academic Program and Outreach Coordinator, this position will play a critical role in capturing scenes from Music events and classes as well as portraits of students and faculty in the Department of Music. This position also engages in communications on behalf of the Department of Music via social media platforms such as Facebook, Instagram, and YouTube. The Photographer/ Social Media Assistant will need to be able to work photography assignments as needed and be flexible in terms of hours and location.
Required Portfolio Instructions:
Candidates must provide original examples of visually engaging photography or video they have captured.
1. Include at least one portrait or a video portrait captured by the candidate.
2. Include at least one action image or a video taken from a performance of music, dance, sport, speech, etc. The photo or video must be captured by the candidate.
Share portfolio via personal website or Google Drive. If sharing via Google Drive, put a link to the Drive folder in your application. Please set Sharing of that folder so any user at Brown with the link may open it.
Other Requirements:
Solid understanding and demonstrated experience working with Instagram, Facebook, and YouTube, among other platforms
The ability to write clearly with proper grammatical skills as well as variance in tone and messaging depending on the social media platform
Self-motivation
Excellent attention to detail
Fluency with photo and/or video editing software (such as Adobe Photoshop)
Preferred Experience:
Experience capturing and editing engaging video content
Some experience with or understanding of different genres of music, including classical, electronic, jazz, and traditional folk forms from around the world, among other styles.

Music Dept.: Studio Technician
Music Dept.: Studio Technician
Apply
Job Description:
The Music Department is seeking students with experience in audio, music and multimedia technology to assist with the maintenance and development of the department’s recording and multimedia production spaces. The student will also provide production support at some music events and for the department’s instructional technology needs. Studio work will include hardware and software installation, facilitating equipment checkout, maintaining studio help documents, and helping with general studio upkeep, scheduling and organization. In addition, the studio technician will be a training resource for new studio users and may occasionally run sessions for department supported projects. Event support will include assisting with sound reinforcement, video and audio recording, and stage management as required.
The studio technician will report to the department’s technical director and work collaboratively with other department staff and student employees.
Requirements:  The candidate must have solid experience with audio technology hardware and software, experience and/or interest in video production is helpful. Experience with the department’s studios is a plus. The work requires the ability to occasionally lift items weighing up to 40 pounds.

IT Fellow
IT Fellow

Job Description:
IT Fellows will provide the following services to faculty and peers:
In-person staffing of lecture hall: Provide help to faculty during lectures, patient presentations, ensure AV equipment is functioning properly for clear delivery of lectures. Set up the computer and AV equipment in the lecture halls and the various case-study and seminar rooms for events, meetings or student interest groups. We expect this to slowly increase in volume through the semester. In the evenings and on weekends, provide technical services to faculty, students and outside groups who wish to hold seminars, conferences or workshops at the Medical School. 
Zoom staffing: Provide help to faculty who are logging into Zoom to give lectures, patient presentations, etc. and troubleshoot technological issues.
It is expected the team of IT fellows wi coordinate so that one student per day was responsible for in-person components and one student per day was responsible for Zoom components. The IT fellows will develop a schedule to ensure that all faculty lecturers have adequate technical support.

Instrumentation Design Mentor ENGN 1230
Instrumentation Design Mentor ENGN 1230
Apply
Job Description:
Instrumentation Design is a hands-on course with many small design projects worked on by small groups in the electronics design workshops (BH095 and BH097). Thus, we need student mentors who have experience with the course to provide informal guidance to students throughout the day, answering practical questions (e.g. "where are the capacitors?" or "how might I think about this problem?" or "can you take a look at my breadboard circuit – it doesn't seem to be doing what I expect it to do?"). Mentors are expected to dedicate at least 6 hours of the week to support the course, 10-12 is preferred. Mentors gain more depth in the course materials through informal teaching and guidance from the professor, as well as experience in mentorship.
Qualifications
Must have taken ENGN1230; have an eagerness to teach and guide fellow students; good handle of the course materials (in particular, basic circuits) and the overall flow of the course.
Students expected to work 10 hours per week from 9/1/2025 - 12/15/2025

Swearer Center Community-Engaged Data and Evaluation Student Worker
Swearer Center Community-Engaged Data and Evaluation Student Worker
Apply
Job Description:
The Community-Engaged Data and Evaluation Student Worker will work with Swearer staff in the Community-Engaged Data and Evaluation Collaborative (CEDEC) to support the data and evaluation priorities of nonprofit and government partners in Rhode Island. The student worker will work closely with the CEDEC Associate Director to advance data and evaluation projects with community partners.
Specific tasks may include:
Converting unstructured data into structured data through data entry and digitizing physical records;
Mapping local, state and national information resources that advance our partners’ data and evaluation priorities;
Building low- to no-code data solutions with community partners;
Communicating and documenting project progress and goals;
Visualizing and analyzing quantitative and/or qualitative data;
Contributing to project sustainability and growth plans with CEDEC staff and community partners.
QUALIFICATIONS
A commitment to social justice and an interest in integrating the work of the University with the work and priorities of community partners;
Required:
Intermediate/advanced skills in spreadsheet software (e.g., Google Sheets, Microsoft Excel);
Capacity and commitment to maintain high standards for data quality and accuracy, as well as confidentiality;
Able to work independently and collaboratively.
Preferred:
Experience with or interest in learning R and/or Python programming languages;
Excellent written and oral communication skills;
LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES
Working closely with Swearer Center staff, the student worker will:
Learn about:
data collection in diverse settings and sectors, including but not limited to housing, workforce development, education, and the environment;
communicating data project objectives across campus and community collaborators;
Tools for data organization, analysis and communication.
Gain the opportunity to learn about university-community partnerships and interact with Swearer Center constituencies (students, faculty, staff, community partners);
Gain exposure to a professional office setting and career paths in engaged scholarship, academic administration, and community-engaged research.
REQUIREMENTS
This position will begin in September 2025 and end in December 2025. If mutually agreed, there is a possibility for an extension through the academic year until May 2026. The role is expected to take up to 10 hours per week during the fall/spring if applicable
The student worker must be enrolled as an undergraduate student (in any program/year) at Brown University at the time of employment.
APPLY
Please submit a resume in Workday with a priority deadline of Aug 8th, 2025.
If you have questions about the position, please contact CEDEC Associate Director Dan Turner at cedec@brown.edu.

2025-07-27

Undergraduate TA for Logic PHIL 0640
Undergraduate TA for Logic PHIL 0640
Apply
Job Description:
The Philosophy department is interested in hiring up to 2 undergraduate teaching assistants (UTAs) for PHIL 0640: Logic. The position will be for the fall semester, working 10 hours a week. UTAs will work under the guidance of the instructor of the course (Prof. Riki Heck) as well as a graduate teaching assistant.
Undergraduate TA duties include:
· Holding weekly TA office hours (both individual and group office hours)
· Grading problem sets and exams
· Responding to student questions by email
· Keeping the instructor informed about student progress
The instructor will make available to the UTAs solution sets and grading guidelines for the problem sets and exams.
Required Experience:
Undergraduate TAs should have taken at least one course in logic, preferably in the Philosophy department (for instance, Logic, Advanced Deductive Logic, or Mathematical Logic), and have an interest in logic.
Application Procedure:
Prospective applicants should submit a one-page description of their background and interest in logic and the reason they are interested in being a UTA. They should also submit a copy of their transcript (an unofficial transcript is fine).
The deadline for applications is August 31th. If there is considerable interest in these positions, applicants may have a short Zoom interview. Final decisions will be made by the start of the fall semester, at the latest.

John Carter Brown Library Reading Room Assistant
John Carter Brown Library Reading Room Assistant
Apply
Job Description:
On Campus Job Opportunity
Located on the main campus green, the John Carter Brown Library (JCB) welcomes individuals and communities from around the world to research, learn, and share knowledge about the early Americas through the use of its collection of historical materials.  We seek friendly, communicative students to assist in the JCB Reading Room.
Typical Duties:
Welcome visitors to the reading room, explain library policies, and direct visitors to exhibition and research areas
Assist reading room staff with monitoring activity in the reading room and other public spaces
Retrieve and reshelve materials from the JCB’s reference collection
Assist the JCB staff with tasks as needed
Our student assistants need to:
Communicate effectively and considerately with diverse audiences
Enjoy engaging with visitors and researchers
Maintain close attention to multiple activities in a busy environment and respond appropriately when needed
Exercise judgment and responsibility when interacting with JCB visitors, staff, and material
Graduate students must be enrolled in a graduate program at Brown and not receiving other financial support from the University; undergraduate students with previous library work or special collections experience will be considered.
To apply, please submit a resume with your application.
Hours: The JCB Reading Room is open Monday-Thursday, 10 am - 1 pm and 2 pm to 5 pm, and Friday, 10 am to 1 pm.  Shifts can be arranged to accommodate availability and academic schedules.

Reporter for Possibly Podcast
Reporter for Possibly Podcast
Apply
Job Description:
Do you wonder about how your choices affect our planet? Have you ever wanted to hear your voice on the radio? 
Join Possibly, a project that connects students with professional journalists and scientists to create a weekly radio program/podcast about sustainability. We’re looking for motivated student reporters interested in media, science and sustainability. Possibly airs weekly on The Public’s Radio 89.3FM, is distributed on the Public Radio Exchange, and has aired in several states around the country. 
We report on topics as different as “should I buy an electric car?”, “which type of milk has the lowest greenhouse gas footprint?”, and “what’s the most efficient way to boil a cup of water?” Our student reporters interview and mix their shows, with professional mentoring, and their work is heard on-air by thousands of listeners. 
Check out past Possibly episodes if this sounds interesting.  Then, if you are interested in joining the team, apply here. The next episode you hear could be yours! 
Hourly Wage: $18 per hour
Job Contact: Nat Hardy, nathaniel_hardy@alumni.brown.edu
Requirements:  
Applicants must have completed an I-9 prior to the first day of work, if they have not already done so. This includes providing Original Unexpired ID to the HR Service Center. Please refer to the Form I-9 List of Acceptable Documents for guidance.
Undergrads studying abroad are not eligible to apply - students located outside the US cannot work or be paid by Brown in Workday, because it's considered foreign-sourced income.

2025-06-05

The purpose of this IBES Undergrad Peer Advisor Program is to pair first-year students (and others) who expressed an interest in Environmental Sciences and Studies with current junior and senior concentrators who can assist them with questions about the curriculum, types of support available to undergrads, options they may not be familiar with, and give a fellow student’s perspective.  The intent is to provide information about our programs and community to students who historically would not consider pursuing ENVS for a concentration.

In order to make this a successful endeavor, we are looking for upcoming juniors and seniors to take on such mentoring. Responsibilities include Peer Advisors creating a slide that can be used introducing them to entry level courses, meeting with interested students a couple times a year, and organizing info sessions & panels.  Mentors may also be called upon to attend a few recruiting events.
Compensation: $18 per hr
Interested students must fill out the following Google questionnaire - IBES Undergraduate Peer Advising Questionnaire 2025-26
Send inquiries to jeannel@brown.edu 
Requirements:
Must be a current Environmental Sciences and Studies Concentrator
Applicants must have completed an I-9 prior to the first day of work, if they have not already done so.  This includes bringing original document(s) showing proof of identity and eligibility for employment to the HR Service Center for review.
Undergrads studying abroad are not eligible to apply - students located outside the US cannot work or be paid by Brown in Workday, because it's considered foreign-sourced income.

Job Description:
Campus Center Evening Managers
Job Description:
The Campus Center Evening Managers are responsible for overall management of the Stephen Robert ‘62 Campus Center during weeknights (5pm - 8pm or 8pm - 11pm) and alternating Saturdays (1-5pm). Evening Managers are a point person for the building who conduct building rounds, assist community members in accessing the building, providing and collecting equipment that has been checked out, and report any problems and/or maintenance issues. The Campus Center Evening Managers will report to the Assistant Director, Stephen Robert ‘62 Campus Center and Student Activities.

Responsibilities:
● Conduct rounds of the campus center several times per shift to ensure safety of all members
● Assist community members in accessing and navigating the building
● Help to troubleshoot A/V in the building
● Provide customer service and answer inquiries at front information desk, acting as a point person for the building during assigned shifts nights and weekends
● Communicate to supervisor on broken or missing equipment, facility problems, or unusual activity and submit work orders as needed
● Attend monthly meetings with supervisor each semester
● Attend 2 SAO student worker engagement series events per semester, including
orientation.

Qualifications:
● Ability to deliver exemplary customer service
● Strong communication and interpersonal skills
● Attention to detail
● Problem solving skills and use of good judgment
● Time management skills
● Good academic standing with the college
● Good judicial standing with the college
Department:
Student Activities Office

Grade:
B

Scheduled Weekly Hours:
● 7-15 hours per week working evenings (5pm-11pm) and alternating Saturdays (1pm-5pm)
Contact: marisa_fortney@brown.edu

Job Description:
Campus Center Programmer
Job Description:
Campus Center Programmers (approximately a team of 4 students) work to support the Student Activities Office (SAO) by developing, organizing, and implementing high-quality, engaging student events for the Stephen Robert ‘62 Campus Center. This role will require students to collaboratively and independently support daytime and evening/weekend programming within the Campus Center, including hosting campus traditions like Halloween and First Fridays, while also supporting new traditions and ideas on a monthly basis.

Responsibilities:
● Attend weekly staff meetings with supervisor and programming team
● Intentionally develop and advertise events for the Stephen Robert ‘62 Campus Center that target a variety of populations (UG, GR, Fac/Staff) via social media, Today@Brown, and through postering
● Staff 5-7 events each semester (fall and spring). Availability First Friday of every month is mandatory
● Manage and rectify a budget for events
● Be informed of SAO event policies and actively seek additional information as needed
● Support the mission and goals of the Student Activities Office
● Attend 2 SAO student worker engagement series events per semester, including
orientation.

Qualifications:
● A passion to be creative and implement innovative and engaging student programs for peers
● Desire to learn and excel at event planning in a team-orientation environment
● Willingness to work on evenings and occasional weekends
● Excellent time management skills to meet deadlines
● Strong communication and interpersonal skills
● Ability to work well and quickly under pressure and within fast-paced environments
● Problem solving skills to both anticipate and react to needed changes
● Must be willing to set up and break down for events which may include lifting or moving items that could weigh up to 50lbs
Department:
Student Activities Office
Scheduled Weekly Hours:
● Hours vary based on the programming calendar throughout the semester.
Programmers can expect to work 15-20 hours during peak times. Hours will be
completed via staff meetings, independent event prep, and during scheduled
programs set-up, duration, and breakdown.
Contact: Marisa_fortney@brown.edu

Job Description:
Job Description
The Student Activities Office Administrative Assistant supports the Student Activities Office (SAO) and the Stephen Robert Campus Center by staffing the SAO main office. The administrative assistant will work closely under the supervision of the Student Activities Coordinator to help create a welcoming and inclusive main office environment.  The administrative assistant acts as the first point of contact for students and community members. They also help to create marketing and visual materials for the Student Activities Office. This role plays an integral part in the success and growth of the Student Activities Office.

Primary Responsibilities:
Staffing the front desk and greeting visitors to the Main Office
Support with maintaining the Main Office clean and orderly
Answering calls and emails and responding appropriately to inquiries
Mail pickup and delivery
Managing SAO equipment reservations
Administrative support with event staffing requests.
Creating flyers for SAO Programming
Designing signage for annual SAO events
Updating bulletin boards and Today@Brown
Help set up for SAO events like Event planning 101, Activities Fair, and Spring Weekend
Other duties as assigned by SAO staff
Requirements:
Ability to create a welcoming and inclusive environment for their peers and community
Comfortable and effective in a fast paced and unpredictable environment
Experience with graphic design in Canva or other platform
Ability to work independently and collaboratively with other SAO student workers
Effective written and verbal communication skills
Interest in promoting diverse and inclusive spaces on campus in line with the SAO mission
Attendance at annual training for all SAO student employees and at least 1 engagement session per semester

Job Description:
Underground Thursdays Program Coordinator
Job Description:
Underground Thursdays is a monthly performing arts series organized by the SAO with a goal of providing a platform to showcase student performance and talent and to build community. We are seeking creative, motivated students who are interested in performing arts to book and host performances, promote events, and brainstorm themes for upcoming events. This position will run for the duration of the Academic Year with the option to stay on for the following year. Both teamwork and the ability to work independently are required skills and experience with
the creative and performing arts or media services is strongly preferred. Attendance at all monthly Thursday evening events is mandatory. Previous engagement with Underground Thursdays as a performer or attendee is appreciated.

Responsibilities:
● Attend weekly staff meetings with supervisor and programming team
● Intentionally develop and advertise events individually and holistically via
Today@Brown, via posters, and through social media
● Organize 4-5 events each semester (fall and spring)
● Manage bookings of performers
● Communicate regularly via email with students and campus community requesting access to Underground AV and potential performers
● Act as point person for Underground AV/equipment and manage coordination of
scheduling, training, and managing maintenance of equipment
● Manage day of set-up, media and equipment set-up, and run of show
● Emcee Thursday events and coordinate appropriate staffing for set-up, duration, and break-down of all events
● Be informed of SAO event policies and actively seek additional information as needed
● Support the mission and goals of the Student Activities Office
● Attend 2 SAO student worker engagement series events per semester, including orientation.

Qualifications:
● Availability Thursday evenings is mandatory
● A passion to be creative and implement innovative and engaging student showcases and opportunities for peers
● Desire to learn and excel at event planning in a team-orientation environment
● Willingness to work on evenings
● Excellent time management skills to meet deadlines
● Strong communication and interpersonal skills
● Ability to work well and quickly under pressure and within fast-paced environments
● Problem solving skills to both anticipate and react to needed changes
● Must be willing to set up and break down for events which may include lifting or moving items that could weigh up to 50lbs
Department:
Student Activities Office
Scheduled Weekly Hours:
● Hours vary based on the programming calendar throughout the semester.
Programmers can expect to work 15-20 hours during peak times. Hours will be
completed via staff meetings, independent event prep, and during scheduled
programs set-up, duration, and breakdown.

**Additional Required Questions:
https://forms.gle/C89C11hZbSs7bAK88
**Email additional questions to marisa_fortney@brown.edu

CPSY 1195_Teaching Assistant_Colwill
Apply
Job Description:
CPSY 1195 (an upper level CURE course called Life under water in the Anthropocene). 
TAs will help with managing the Canvas course website, preparation for zebrafish research projects, editing programs for control of experiments, egg collection and larval rearing, zebrafish husbandry and feeding, and use of SPSS for data analysis. Ideally, TAs will need to be available for class on Tuesdays 1.00 pm - 5:00 pm, for prep and/or cleanup before and after class, to attend a weekly TA meeting and help with zebrafish research projects outside of class time (including some weekends, mainly in October). TAs will need to have completed university sanctioned training including Animal Research Orientation and Training, Laboratory Safety Training and Hazardous Waste Training, and PI supervised training in larval zebrafish handling before the Fall semester begins. Preference will be given to applicants with experience working with zebrafish and/or who have taken CPSY 1195. On average, you should expect to spend 8-10 hours a week as a TA for this course and be available on weekends.

Professional Pathways Research and Coordination Fall 2025 Student Worker
Professional Pathways Research and Coordination Fall 2025 Student Worker
Apply
Job Description:
The Professional Pathways team at the Brown Center for Career Exploration develops in-depth resources and programs for students interested in specific careers across several different pathways. This team also supports career counselors with the pathway-specific tools and knowledge needed to guide students through the exploration of diverse career paths.
The Research and Coordination Fall 2025 Student Workers have a crucial role in enriching the career exploration journey for students by developing inclusive resources and coordinating equitable programs for one of three Professional Pathways. Each position directly contributes to the career success of peers by fostering comprehensive preparation for various industries and opportunities.
Job Description (3-5 hours a week; details differ slightly depending on Pathway)
Communication and Teamwork: Efficiently share information and perspectives both within and outside the organization. Foster collaborative relationships, valuing diverse viewpoints and shared goals.
Plan, coordinate, and market career-field specific workshops and programs.
Assist in the planning and logistics for spring break trips for students in Science & Engineering, and Finance & Consulting.
Improve, develop, maintain, and deploy career field-specific online resources, including the Career Resource Library and a comprehensive resume and portfolio library showcasing great examples from Brown juniors, seniors, and recent graduates for one or more of the Pathways.
Improve the visibility and user-friendliness of our online resources through strategic communication efforts.
Critical Thinking: Recognize and address needs by analyzing the situation and relevant information logically.
Identify and address training and resource needs specific to one Professional Pathway for Peer Career Advisors and Career Counselors.
Research and curate the most valuable career-specific external resources on our website -- including career field-specific job sites, ensuring they are effectively utilized by students.
Equity & Inclusion: Exhibit the awareness, attitude, knowledge, and skills necessary to inclusively engage with diverse cultures from around the world. Engage in practices that actively challenge the systems, structures, and policies of oppression.
Consult with student groups representing diverse backgrounds to develop the aforementioned resources and programs with a focus on making them inclusive and equitable.
Qualifications
While we welcome prior work experience, it's not a requirement. More important are your curiosity and a strong desire to learn the skills needed to succeed in this role.
Strong written and oral communication skills.
Eagerness to reach out to and recruit alumni for various events.
Creative problem-solving skills and the ability to innovate with limited resources.
Training and Supervision
This employee has the freedom to independently manage and complete tasks. At the same time, the hiring manager will provide training and supervision reflective of the level of experience the candidate brings to the position, as well as connections with resources and people to facilitate success.
Compensation: $16 per hour
To Apply
We are hiring one intern for each of the following Professional Pathways:
Careers in the Common Good
Science & Engineering
Technology & Tech Ventures
Submit a resume and cover letter no later than Friday, Aug. 15 at 12:00 noon, detailing which Pathway you’re interested in and why, your interest in the position, and what makes you a standout candidate.
Interviews will take place via Zoom in August and the start date for the position is on or about Sept. 15.
Learn more about the Center for Career Exploration’s Professional Pathways at https://career-center.brown.edu/pathways-outcomes.

Fall 2025 CHEM0330 UTA - Rose Petruck
Apply
Job Description:
Job Description: CHEM0330 undergraduate TAs will be expected to: o Lead a 1-hour group problem solving session (GPS) primarily in-person, but also potentially remotely, once per week. Students will help their peers through homework problems and GPS packets; o Maintain a 1-hour per week office hour scheduled at their convenience for CH330 students to attend to have any of their additional questions addressed; o Attend weekly check-ins and trainings for roughly 1-hour per week; o Spend 1-2 hours per week preparing to lead their GPS sessions and reviewing the relevant material; o In some cases, organize and lead additional review sessions for students struggling with the material or before exams. Depending upon the case, this could amount to an additional 1-hour per week of work. o Contribute to weekly, TA-driven problem packets that can be used in TA-led help sessions and GPS. This amounts to an average commitment of 4-5 hours per week. Beyond these explicit tasks, students will be expected to regularly read and answer pertinent emails, and maintain communication with Prof. Rubenstein regarding the class via email, Canvas, and Slack. Prerequisites: In order to apply, students should have successfully completed (received an A or high B in) CH330 during a previous semester at Brown, demonstrated an interest in teaching/mentoring their peers through previous educational/outreach experiences, completed the CH330 interest form, and successfully interviewed for the position . Students need not be STEM or chemistry concentrators to be considered, but should be fluent in Chemistry.
