Graduate Student Ambassador
Graduate Student Ambassador
Apply
Job Description:
Position Overview:
The Department of Education is seeking to hire four Graduate Student Ambassadors (two Urban
Education Policy students and two Master of Arts in Teaching students) who demonstrate a
distinctive ability to present critical and fair student perspectives on the graduate program.
Student Ambassadors exhibit a passion for the program and the Education department’s
mission, demonstrate excellent communication and interpersonal skills, and have a personable
demeanor. They will assist their respective program director and Kara McCrudden, the
Marketing Communications and Recruitment Manager, in the recruitment, enrollment, and
communications efforts associated with the program.
The Ambassadors will serve as an important point of contact for potential and admitted
graduate students, serve as program representatives at various department and
program-related functions, and help to develop digital content that supports recruitment and
enrollment efforts.
Primary tasks will include:
● Attending bi-weekly meetings with Kara and other ambassadors to discuss projects
and future plans;
● Speaking with prospects, applicants, and/or admitted students (virtually or in-person)
who are interested in learning more about the program from the perspective of a
currently enrolled student;
● Connecting with fellow students, program faculty, and alumni to create and coordinate
content for the website and social media platforms, such as Person Spotlights and
Instagram Takeovers;
● Advising on and facilitating outreach to various student organizations and Departmental
Undergraduate Groups (DUGs) to help promote the program to Brown undergraduate
students;
● Hosting small group chats with prospective students throughout the recruitment cycle;
● Disseminating marketing materials around campus by, for example, tabling on the green,
handing out flyers at specific events, and hanging posters around campus;
● Serving as a resource for improving student recruitment locally, regionally, and
nationally;
● Assisting with social media content creation;
● Representing the department and offering logistical support at information sessions
(in-person or digital), Student Admit Day (Spring 2026), and Education Department
events;
● Other tasks as assigned.
Benefits of the Role:
● Develop valuable leadership skills
● Enhance your communications, interpersonal, and networking skills
● Meet future students and network with program alumni
● Develop content creation skills by helping to create intriguing and authentic stories for
social media and websites
● Gain a deeper understanding of university-level recruitment and communications
strategies
Qualifications:
● Currently enrolled in the UEP or MAT program
● Excellent interpersonal skills
● Demonstrated strong written communication and presentation skills
● Knowledge and command of evolving social media platforms and strategies
● Demonstrated ability to support a community of diverse perspectives and cultures in an
inclusive environment.
Compensation and Time Commitment:
The Ambassador(s) will receive an hourly wage of $20.00 for approximately 2-6 hours per week.
The Education Department reserves the right to remove any student from the Ambassador
position should they be unable to perform the above duties. The Ambassadors will start on
September 8, 2025, and continue through April 2026.
Part-time UEP students are eligible to apply and may have the opportunity to extend their
employment into their second year.
Recruiting Start Date:
2025-07-23

Are you interested in gaining research experience in cognitive science and linguistics? The Brown Language and Thought Lab is searching for a research assistant to work on projects related to how children reason about the world and learn language. Join our team!

·      coding data from babies and kids’ looking and behavior
·      creating/editing videos with Adobe Premiere Pro or PowerPoint for study de sign

When: Starting as soon as possible, ideally beginning of September until December break. Preferably 10-20 hr/week; hours can be flexible depending on your availability.

Student Social Media Liaison

Job Description:
The Watson Institute for International and Public Affairs is seeking a motivated Student Social Media Liaison to help create organic content for Watson’s social media channels. The Student Social Media Liaison will also work directly with the Digital Content Specialist to track social media trends, peer analysis and understanding our social media analytics. 
Responsibilities: 
Content creation: Assist in the creation of engaging and relevant content for various social media platforms, such as Facebook, X (Twitter), Instagram, and LinkedIn. This may include writing captions, editing photos or videos, and scheduling posts.
Research and analysis: Conduct research on social media trends, best practices, and peer analysis to provide insights and recommendations for improving Watson’s social media presence.
Campaign support: Assist in the planning, coordination, and execution of social media campaigns or initiatives, such as promoting events, news, and student spotlights.
Community engagement: Actively engage with the university's social media community, actively participate and follow any hashtags or campaigns they may be running so that Watson can contribute. Identify opportunities for collaboration or partnerships across campus.
Collaboration and coordination: Collaborate with other members of the social media team, student organizations, as well as the centers, initiatives, and programs at Watson to gather information and coordinate content creation. Attend biweekly meetings with Watson’s Digital Content Specialist to develop content and discuss strategy.
Stay up-to-date: Be aware of the latest social media trends, algorithm changes, and emerging platforms to suggest new strategies that could enhance Watson’s social media presence.
Photography and videography: Capture photos and videos of events, life at Watson, and other activities that can be used for social media content.
Adherence to policies and guidelines: Follow the university’s social media policies.
Qualifications:
Proficient with social media especially Instagram and TikTok
Experience with planner tools such as Hootsuite and Meta Business Suite Planner
Experience with editing tools such as Canva or Adobe suite
Strong communication skills
Detail-oriented and works well with a team
Time management and adherence to deadlines
Interest in International and Public Affairs
Watson student or related major

Independent Studies (IS) Coordinator
Independent Studies (IS) Coordinator
Apply
Job Description:
About the CRC
The Curricular Resource Center for Peer Advising (CRC) is a community of advisors who assist students in engaging with Brown's Open Curriculum and making effective use of its academic resources. Established in 1976 to promote optimal engagement with the New Curriculum, the CRC's full-time staff, student coordinators, and volunteers host information sessions, community-building events, and individual meetings. These meetings provide guidance on independent studies, concentrations, applying for funding, issues related to the sophomore year, and more. Additionally, the CRC staff collaborates with other departments and peer advising programs to offer a wide range of advice about Brown's extensive curricular resources. The CRC operates as part of the College.
Position
The Independent Studies (IS) program is one of the original signature programs at the Curricular Resource Center. The IS student Co-Coordinators work with the CRC Director, who is the Associate Dean of the College and Chair of the Independent Concentrations subcommittee of the College Curriculum Council (CCC). They advise students interested in proposing a Group Independent Study Project (GISP), Independent Study Project (ISP), internship for credit/academic internship (AI), or departmental independent study (DISP).
The IS Coordinators hold regular drop-in advising hours, respond to numerous email requests sent to the IS email account, and facilitate information sessions about the IS program and the proposal process. They also serve as members of the IS subcommittee, the selection committee, and collaborate with other students and faculty members from the CCC. They assist the CRC Director in ensuring that the IS materials and guidelines are well-publicized and up-to-date both in hard copy and on the IS website. Additionally, they work to foster a sense of community among students engaged in independent study.
Furthermore, all CRC program coordinators help achieve the center’s overall advising goals. They take part in Orientation, arrange CRC open houses, hold drop-in hours, and are ready to offer general advice on all CRC programs and topics of interest to students.
Job Requirements
Demonstrated interest in the Curricular Resource Center’s mission statement and goals.
Prior experience advising others about opportunities and resources.
Demonstrated ability to articulate the process of proposing an independent concentration.
Excited to promote independent studies and to create a community of students.
Motivated and energetic; friendly, patient, and approachable.
Demonstrated skill and sensitivity when working with private information.
Ability to work independently and collaboratively on various tasks/projects in an office setting.
Attention to detail and ability to follow through on a project from start to finish.
Strong written communication skills.
Capable of planning events and public speaking.
Hours: 8 -12 hours per week
Hourly Rate: $17.00/hour
Application
To apply, please submit an application in the Workday portal and include a cover letter and resume. Applications will be reviewed on a rolling basis.
Questions: Contact Peggy Chang, Peggy_Chang@brown.edu

ENGN 0010 Grader, National Education Equity Lab
ENGN 0010 Grader, National Education Equity Lab
Apply
Job Description:
Brown University and the National Education Equity Lab are partnering to offer Brown University college courses to eligible high schools across the country. With your help and support, students from our nation’s most underserved communities can gain access to a rigorous college course and have the opportunity to earn academic college credit while in high school. As a Brown University and National Education Equity Grader, you will engage students in providing support for the instructor as well as grading student work, participating in weekly instructional team meetings, drive student success, and be part of a national community working to advance education equity.
Graders will assist Professor Karen Haberstroh with the course ENGN 0010 Introduction to Engineering Design, Materials and Structure.      
The purpose of the course is to introduce students to the profession of engineering and the important role engineers play in society, as well as to provide a foundation for further study in engineering. The course begins with the consideration of engineering design and introduces a number of tools that are fundamental to engineering. These may include vectors, computer aided design (CAD), and basic programming (Matlab). Particular attention is then focused on mechanics of materials and the analysis of static structures, but topics also include professional ethics and the social responsibility of engineers
JOB DESCRIPTION
Graders are Brown undergraduate students that provide services as course assistants, which will normally include grading student papers, student projects and  examinations. Class attendance for graders is optional and they are not required to interact directly with the students.
 Among the tasks a Grader is expected to do are:
Collecting assignments and recording completion of work
Communicating with students missing assignments
Provide students with clarifications on assignments
Grading student papers, research projects and  examinations
May also include: attendance at lectures, office hours, weekly instructional team meetings, consultation with instructors
Other duties as assigned
Graders are not allowed to perform teaching duties
COMPENSATION
Graders are compensated hourly for the work performed and earn $15.00/hr.  All graders are required to submit timesheets for their hours worked. Graders may not work more than 20 hours per week. 

QUALIFICATIONS
Enrolled Brown undergraduate student
Solid understanding of coursework in the subject area
Background Check: Since this work may involve direct interaction with students who are minors, completion of a successful background check is required.

2025-07-23

Independent Concentration (IC) Coordinator
Apply
Job Description:
About the CRC: 
The Curricular Resource Center (CRC) is a community of peer and full-time advisors, mentors, and educators who support student engagement with academics and the Brown curriculum. We offer drop-in hours and a range of programming designed to help students connect to and utilize Brown's academic resources. Our collective goal is to help students feel a sense of agency in making decisions and see the realm of possibilities for their college experience.
The CRC was founded in 1976 to support the Open Curriculum. The CRC's full-time staff, student program coordinators, and student volunteer mentors and leaders lead information sessions, community-building events, and individual advising meetings. These focus on navigating and accessing the Open Curriculum, building academic communities, and exploring opportunities for deep engagement and high-impact learning. The CRC staff works with various campus groups, centers, and educators to offer the best guidance on Brown's academic resources and beyond. The CRC is part of The College division.
Position: 
The Independent Concentration program is a key part of the Curricular Resource Center’s offerings. The IC student Coordinators collaborate with the CRC Director, who is the Associate Dean of the College and Chair of the Independent Concentrations subcommittee of the College Curriculum Council. They guide students interested in developing an independent concentration from their initial interest through to full approval.
The IC Coordinators hold regular drop-in advising hours, respond to numerous email requests to the IC email account, and organize information sessions about the IC program and proposal process. They also serve as members of the IC subcommittee and selection committee. They assist the CRC Director in ensuring that the IC materials and guidelines are well-publicized and kept up-to-date in hard copy and on the IC website. Additionally, they lead the IC DUG (Departmental Undergraduate Group) and work to foster a sense of community among the independent concentrators.
Additionally, all CRC program coordinators contribute to the success of the center’s overall advising goals. They participate in Orientation, coordinate CRC open houses, hold drop-in hours, and are ready to offer general guidance about all CRC programs and topics of interest to students.
Job Requirements:
Demonstrated interest in the Curricular Resource Center’s mission statement and goals.
Prior experience advising others about opportunities and resources.
Demonstrated ability to articulate the process of proposing an independent concentration.
Excited to promote ICs and to create a community of independent concentrators.
Motivated and energetic; friendly, patient, and approachable.
Demonstrated skill and sensitivity when working with private information.
Ability to work independently and collaboratively on various tasks/projects in an office setting.
Attention to detail and ability to follow through on a project from start to finish.
Strong written communication skills.
Capable of planning events and public speaking.
Hours: 8 -12 hours per week
Hourly Rate: $17.00/hour
Application:

Theories in Action (TiA) Coordinator
Theories in Action (TiA) Coordinator
Apply
Job Description:
About the CRC
The Curricular Resource Center for Peer Advising (CRC) is a community of advisors who assist students in engaging with Brown's Open Curriculum and effectively using its academic resources. Established in 1976, the CRC was created to support active engagement with the New Curriculum. Its full-time staff, student coordinators, academic coaches, and volunteers organize information sessions, community-building events, and one-on-one meetings to advise students on independent studies, concentrations, funding opportunities, issues during the sophomore year, developing academic skills, and more. Additionally, the CRC collaborates with other departments and peer advising programs to offer a wide range of guidance on Brown's extensive curricular resources. The CRC is part of the College.
Position
Theories in Action (TiA) is an interdisciplinary conversation, held during the spring semester, enabling undergraduates to share and showcase their research, leadership activities, artistic productions, community engagement and other worthwhile endeavors. Since 2010, TiA has provided hundreds of Independent Concentrators and other students with an annual forum to share their work with and beyond the Brown community through roundtable and poster sessions, resulting in a rich exchange of ideas and learning.  Beginning in the fall semester, the TiA Coordinator begins planning and acts as the main contact for Independent Concentration seniors and other senior-year students interested in participating in the symposium. The TiA Coordinator oversees all aspects of the symposium, including hosting information sessions, recruiting participants, developing and distributing applications to present at TiA, assisting students in preparing their presentations, promoting the event to the wider community, and coordinating these activities with support from other CRC staff as needed. Additionally, all CRC program coordinators support the center’s overall advising objectives. They participate in Orientation, organize CRC open houses, hold drop-in hours, and are available to offer general advice about all CRC programs and topics that interest students.
Job Requirements
Demonstrated interest in the Curricular Resource Center’s mission statement and goals.
Prior experience with academic advising.
Prior experience with event planning and communications.
Excited to promote TiA to potential participants and audiences.
Motivated and energetic; friendly, patient, and approachable.
Ability to work independently and collaboratively on various tasks/projects in an office setting.
Attention to detail and ability to follow through on a project from start to finish.
Comfortable with public speaking.
Preference is given to non-seniors.
Hours: 8 -10 hours per week
Hourly Rate: $16.00/hour to start.
Application
To apply, please submit an application in the Workday portal and include a cover letter and resume. Applications will be reviewed on a rolling basis.

Academic Coach
Academic Coach
Apply
Job Description:
About the CRC: 
The Curricular Resource Center for Peer Advising (CRC) is a community of advisors/coaches/mentors who help students engage with Brown's Open Curriculum and effectively utilize its academic resources. The CRC was established in 1976 to support optimal engagement with the New Curriculum. The CRC's full-time staff, student program coordinators, peer academic coaches, and volunteer mentors facilitate information sessions, community-building events, and individual meetings with students to provide advising on independent studies and concentrations, applying for funding opportunities, issues related to the sophomore year, building academic skills and capacity, and more. In addition, the CRC staff collaborates with other departments and peer advising programs to offer a comprehensive range of guidance on Brown's extensive curricular resources. The CRC is a part of the College.
Job Description: 
As part of the AcCESs program, Academic Coaches are undergraduate upper-class students (juniors or seniors) or graduate students at Brown who assist undergraduate students in discovering their learning styles and developing effective study strategies for their academic success and engagement.
These one-on-one sessions and group-oriented workshops enable students to:
Develop individualized study habits, test-taking skills, and plans for assignments
Enhance broader academic skills, including time management and effective strategies for preparing for exams
Work on assignments from incomplete courses
Discuss and explore self-care and wellness strategies that will help them stay healthy while they study
Reflect upon their academic goals, personal aspirations, and values as they relate to their academic experience at Brown
Find the appropriate campus resources to enhance their academics and time management
Stay motivated and focused on their academic and extracurricular activities
By developing individualized strategies to study effectively and overcome setbacks, we promote resiliency and growth in the classroom and beyond.
Job Responsibilities/Expectations:
Students with backgrounds in STEM and economics are especially encouraged to apply, although we welcome applicants from all academic fields. Academic coaches oversee three main areas:
Scheduling and conducting individual meetings with students to determine their study habits and enhance their learning strategies. Coaches typically work with five students and meet with their coachees once a week or every two weeks.
Academic Coaches are also responsible for curating and facilitating workshop sessions and study groups for undergraduate students throughout the semester, covering topics such as reading strategies, note-taking, test preparation, and time management.
Coaches also hold individual and group drop-in/open-hour sessions for any undergraduate student interested in support.
Coaches participate in pre-semester training, weekly team meetings, and self- and program evaluations. Coaches can expect to hold some evening and weekend hours conducting workshops or individual student consultations. Other expectations include:
Demonstrated interest in the Curricular Resource Center’s mission statement and goals.
Prior experience advising, coaching, or mentoring others about opportunities and resources.
Prior experience working with neurodiverse individuals, within communities of color, and with students from under-represented/minoritized communities.
Motivated and energetic; friendly, patient, and approachable.
Ability to work independently and collaboratively on various tasks/projects in an office setting.
Attention to detail and ability to follow through on a project from start to finish.
Capable of planning events and public speaking.
Excellent written communication skills.
How to Apply:
Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis. All information is kept on file, and you will only be contacted if granted an interview. Interviews are 20 minutes long. To apply: Apply for the job in the Workday portal. Please include a resume and cover letter.
The position pays $17.00 per hour. We seek applicants with experience in student advising, support, and peer mentorship. The role requires a commitment of approximately 6 to 8 hours per week. We especially welcome applicants who demonstrate a commitment to academic advising, inclusion, and belonging.
Primary Contact: Faith Freeman, CRC Program Manager
Email Address: faith_freeman@brown.edu

2025-07-13

Job Description:
About the CRC: 
The Curricular Resource Center for Peer Advising (CRC) is a community of advisors who assist students in engaging with Brown's Open Curriculum and making effective use of its academic resources. Established in 1976, the CRC supports active engagement with the New Curriculum. Its full-time staff, student coordinators, academic coaches, and volunteers organize information sessions, community-building events, and individual meetings for advising on independent studies, concentrations, funding opportunities, sophomore-year issues, developing academic skills, and more. Additionally, the CRC staff collaborates with other departments and peer advising programs to provide comprehensive guidance on Brown's extensive curricular resources. The CRC is part of the College.
Position: 
The Matched Advising Program for Sophomores (MAPS) is an important peer advising resource that assists around 200 sophomores each year. MAPS matches junior and senior peers with sophomores who share similar academic and other interests. The program also organizes activities such as a kick-off event for mentors and mentees, training sessions for mentors, study breaks, and various events open to the entire sophomore class. These include a concentration workshop and meetings covering other topics relevant to sophomores, such as study abroad, research opportunities, leavetaking, and more.
The Coordinators promote the program to sophomores and recruit mentors to meet the needs, interests, and strengths of mentee applicants. They train the mentors and serve as a contact point for all program members. They also regularly survey participants to assess and improve the programming. Additionally, all CRC program coordinators support the center’s advising goals. They participate in Orientation, organize CRC open houses, hold office hours, and are ready to provide general advice about all CRC programs and topics relevant to students.
Job Requirements
Demonstrated interest in the Curricular Resource Center’s mission statement and goals.
Prior experience with academic advising.
Prior experience with event planning and communications.
Motivated and energetic; friendly, patient, and approachable.
Ability to work independently and collaboratively on various tasks/projects in an office setting.

Combined Baccalaureate/MAT Student Ambassador
Combined Baccalaureate/MAT Student Ambassador
Apply
Job Description:
Position Overview:
The Department of Education is looking to hire one Combined Baccalaureate/MAT Student
Ambassador who is an undergraduate student and has been admitted into the program. This
person will help us to strengthen our undergraduate student pipeline and will demonstrate a
distinctive ability to present critical and fair student perspectives of the program.
Student Ambassadors exhibit a passion for the program and the Education department’s
mission, demonstrate excellent communication and interpersonal skills, and have a personable
demeanor. They will assist the MAT program director, Professor Katie Rieser, and Kara
McCrudden, the Marketing Communications and Recruitment Manager, in the recruitment,
enrollment, and communications efforts associated with the program.
The Ambassador will serve as an important point of contact for potential and admitted graduate
students, serve as program representatives at various department and program-related
functions, and help to develop digital content that supports recruitment and enrollment efforts.
Primary tasks will include:
● Attending bi-weekly meetings with Kara and other student ambassadors to discuss
projects and future plans;
● Helping to promote the department’s undergraduate concentration and DUG activities;
● Speaking with prospects, applicants, and/or admitted students (virtually or in-person)
who are interested in learning more about the program from the perspective of a currently
enrolled student;
● Connecting with fellow students, program faculty, and alumni to create and coordinate
content for the website and social media platforms that highlights the undergraduate
experience, such as Person Spotlights and Instagram Takeovers;
● Advising on and facilitating outreach to various student organizations and Departmental
Undergraduate Groups (DUGs) to help promote the program to Brown undergraduate
students;
● Hosting small group chats with prospective students throughout the recruitment cycle;
● Disseminating marketing materials around campus by, for example, tabling on the green,
handing out flyers at specific events, and hanging posters around campus;
● Serving as a resource for improving student recruitment among Brown undergraduates;
● Assisting with social media content creation;
● Representing the department and offering logistical support at information sessions and
Education Department events;
● Other tasks as assigned.
Benefits:
● Develop valuable leadership skills
● Enhance your communications, interpersonal, and networking skills
● Meet future students and network with program alumni
● Develop content creation skills by helping to create intriguing and authentic stories for
social media and websites
Qualifications:
● Brown undergraduate student
● Admitted to the Combined Baccalaureate/MAT program
● Excellent interpersonal skills
● Demonstrated strong written communication and presentation skills
● Knowledge and command of evolving social media platforms and strategies
● Demonstrated ability to support a community of diverse perspectives and cultures in an
inclusive environment.
Compensation and Time Commitment:
The Ambassador(s) will receive an hourly wage of $18.00 for approximately 2-6 hours per week.
The Education Department reserves the right to remove any student from the Ambassador
position should they be unable to perform the above duties. The Ambassador will start on
September 8, 2025, and continue through April 2026

2025-07-23

ENGL 1760Z Teaching Fellow, National Education Equity Lab
ENGL 1760Z Teaching Fellow, National Education Equity Lab
Apply
Job Description:
Brown University and the National Education Equity Lab are partnering to offer Brown University college courses to eligible high schools across the country. With your help and support, students from our nation’s most underserved communities can gain access to a rigorous college course and have the opportunity to earn academic college credit while in high school. As a Brown University and National Education Equity Teaching Fellow, you will engage students in synchronous discussions, hold weekly office hours, grade student work, drive student success, and be part of a national community working to advance education equity.
Teaching Fellows will assist Professor Ravit Reichman with the course ENGL 1760Z, Law and Literature. 
This course considers how law and literature contribute jointly to our sense of justice and our understanding of injustice. Through novels, poetry, film, legal writings, and legal opinions that have shaped our history, we examine how law and literature are connected to cultural issues like identity, sexuality, injury, policing, and love. Together, we will work to discover connections between how we read, respond to, understand a story or event from the past, and how this understanding generates our sense of justice and our ideas of responsibility. 
JOB DESCRIPTION
Teaching Fellows are Brown advanced undergraduate or graduate students who teach in areas in which they have developing expertise from the course structure designed by the faculty instructor.  Fellows are required to meet weekly with a co-teacher (teacher from a partner high school depending on the co-teacher schedule), meet weekly with faculty instructor and other teaching fellows, hold weekly online office hours, and teach online weekly to 30-40 high school students. A Fellow may attend the live sessions that are led by a representative from the National Education Equity Lab and a faculty instructor. In addition, they may be asked to provide additional support to the instructor and the students in ways that increase – in quality and quantity – student contact with content experts and, in this way, supports student learning. 
While a Teaching Fellow should be viewed by students as an instructional resource, they are not responsible for creating a syllabus, designing and delivering course content independent of the instructor, or creating individual class modules and lecturers. Teaching Fellows typically work, on average, approximately 20  hours per week.
 Among the tasks a Teaching Fellow is expected to do are:
Teach content as structured and designed by the faculty instructor 
Lead and facilitate approximately 45-minute weekly synchronous discussion sections 
Grade and provide students with feedback on homework, exams, tests, written papers, and other assignments
Attend weekly meetings with co-teacher (teacher from a partner high school) depending on co-teaching schedule 
Hold weekly online office hours
Attend weekly meetings with other Teaching Fellows, faculty instructor and representatives from National Education Equity Lab
Tutor students on how to learn (i.e. going over study strategies)
Assist the instructor with administering pre‐instruction and/or post‐instruction 
Provide formative feedback to the instructor regarding student learning
Act as a “liaison” between the instructor and students
COMPENSATION
Teaching Fellows are compensated hourly for the work performed. Teaching Fellows are paid $22.50/hour. All Teaching Fellows are required to submit timesheets for their hours worked. Teaching Fellows are scheduled to work an estimated 10-15 hours per week.
QUALIFICATIONS
Current Brown students (if undergraduate, must have senior or junior standing) with expertise in the discipline being taught and with specific content expertise in the special area being taught; 
Prior experience as a teaching assistant or training in pedagogy recommended

PLEASE NOTE:  Since this work involves direct interaction with students who are minors, successful completion of a background check and the Expectations for Working with Minors training is required in order to be hired.

2025-04-28

Student Assistant to the Office of the Chief
Student Assistant to the Office of the Chief
Apply
Job Description:
Job Description
The Student Assistant to the Office of the Chief provides direct support to the Brown University Department of Public Safety (DPS) executive leadership team, specifically the Deputy Chief of Police/Executive Officer and the Vice President for Public Safety and Emergency Management. This position assists with a range of strategic, technical, and administrative projects that enhance the department’s operational effectiveness, innovation, and community engagement.
The assistant will be involved in project coordination, data analysis, event planning, and technology integration support—offering exposure to institutional strategy, public safety technologies, and university-wide collaboration. This is an excellent opportunity for students interested in law enforcement operations, public sector strategy, or organizational management.
Responsibilities
Assist the Deputy Chief of Police/Executive Officer and Vice President for Public Safety and Emergency Management with high-priority initiatives and special projects.
Support data collection and analysis efforts tied to department performance metrics, including response times, communications activity, and strategic goals.
Assist with tracking progress and logistics for major departmental projects, such as public safety system upgrades, digital dashboards, or grant-supported technology initiatives.
Help coordinate logistics for meetings with internal university partners and external vendors (e.g., scheduling, note-taking, follow-up documentation).
Contribute to the preparation of reports, briefings, and internal communications for senior leadership.
Conduct research on best practices in public safety innovation, law enforcement technology, and campus safety models.
Provide general office support to executive staff, including document preparation, project tracking, and file organization.
Participate in internal working groups or strategic planning efforts as assigned.
Qualifications
Strong organizational skills and ability to manage multiple assignments simultaneously.
Excellent written and verbal communication skills.
Interest in public safety, university operations, technology integration, or strategic planning.
Familiarity with Google Workspace and Microsoft Office Suite (especially Excel and PowerPoint).
Experience with basic data analysis or visualization tools (e.g., Canva, Tableau, Power BI) is a plus.
Professionalism, discretion, and ability to handle confidential information.

2025-07-07

Athletics Tutor
Athletics Tutor
Apply
Job Description:
Brown University Athletics is seeking sophomores, juniors and seniors to provide tutoring services to student-athletes. The primary responsibilities of the Athletics Tutor is to support student-athletes to become independent learners, persist in college, and reach their academic goals. Tutors will provide regularly scheduled individual tutoring sessions to clarify and review concepts taught in class, explain processes and promote the use of appropriate study strategies. Tutoring supports classroom-centered activities, and as such, the emphasis and content of the tutoring sessions is determined by the student-athlete's needs. Tutors will be able to build their own schedule with their student-athletes, according to need and availability. High-need subject areas: APMA, BIOL, CHEM, ECON, ENGN, MATH PHYS.
Requirements:
Attend all tutoring meetings, professional development activities and mandatory training sessions
Completed relevant course with a B or higher
Must be in good academic standing
Effective time management and communication skills
Organizational skills and punctuality
Recognize different learning styles and student preferences
Create a professional and welcoming environment by modeling respect for students’ diverse cultures, language skills, and experiences
Use active listening strategies to allow student to determine content and pace of tutoring
Utilize listening and questioning strategies as the primary tutoring method to diagnose student needs and monitor progress 
Utilize feedback and reflection to improve practice 
Recognize primary role to help students become more confident, more successful, self directed learners 
Make appropriate referrals to other campus and community resources as needed
Able to work a minimum of 5 hours per week
Please keep in mind that tutors are matched with tutees based on need and request of courses. If hired, tutors will be contacted when their courses are needed.  Violations of the Academic Code or Student Code of Conduct will result in removal as a tutor.
Compensation: $18/hr

The primary responsibilities of the Athletics Tutor is to support student-athletes to become independent learners, persist in college, and reach their academic goals. Tutors will provide regularly scheduled individual tutoring sessions to clarify and review concepts taught in class, explain processes and promote the use of appropriate study strategies. Tutoring supports classroom-centered activities, and as such, the emphasis and content of the tutoring sessions is determined by the student-athlete's needs. Tutors will be able to build their own schedule with their student-athletes, according to need and availability. High-need subject areas: APMA, BIOL, CHEM, ECON, ENGN, MATH PHYS.

Meiklejohn Leader
Meiklejohn Leader
Apply
Job Description:
Thank you so much for your interest in being a Meiklejohn Leader! Meiklejohn Leadership is a unique  shared learning opportunity that allows you to deepen your own knowledge and connection to campus by helping to welcome and support the newest undergraduate students to Brown. You will partner with other Meiklejohns, Meiklejohn Leaders and Deans of The College to form a warm bond over the year and especially support peer advising at Brown and students in UNIV0123 
As a Meiklejohn Leader, you will manage, support, and communicate with a group of 25-35 Meiklejohns during the year. Responsibilities in the Fall include: attending Leader Orientation; organizing a community-building event for Meiklejohns during Fall Orientation; conducting check-ins with your Meiklejohn group; workshopping the syllabus of UNIV0123; and supporting TA hiring for UNIV0123.
In the Spring, Leaders are expected to serve as Teaching Assistants (TA) for UNIV0123, approximately 6-8 hours/week. TA duties include: attending a pre-term TA retreat and weekly TA sessions with Deans of the College; creating weekly discussion prompts for sections and co-leading sections; leading 1-2 panels during lecture; attending lecture; holding 1 hour office hours; and grading assignments. Other Spring responsibilities include creating and reading Meiklejohn and Meiklejohn Leader applications and conducting Meiklejohn Leader interviews.
Year-Long Responsibilities:
1. Sending emails to your Meiklejohn group
2. Managing the Meiklejohn email inbox
3. Working in committees to improve the program
Communications & Social Media
Applications
Training & Engagement
Assessments, Data, & Reporting
4. Teaching Assistants (TA) for UNIV 0123
5. Attending pre-term TA Retreat and weekly TA meetings
Pre-term TA Retreat date: the Tuesday before spring 2026 courses resume
Weekly TA Meeting times: TBD
6. Working in committees to improve the course
Curriculum
Canvas Support
Campus Partnerships
7. Attending weekly Leadership meetings
8. Liaising with Deans of The College
9. Planning campus-wide events that enhance advising (e.g. pre-registration office hours)
10. Serving as Leader of the Week once a semester
11. Other duties as assigned
Meiklejohn Leaders will receive hourly pay, at $18/hr. 
Meiklejohn Leaders are expected to return to campus early for MANDATORY LEADERSHIP TRAINING. If you have conflicts during pre-orientation, you are expected to prioritize Meiklejohn Leadership training. Please email meiklejohn@brown.edu if you have any questions.
Position Start Date: August 20, 2025
Note: This position is limited to students who applied to be a Meiklejohn Peer Advisor during the Spring 2025 semester.

Recovery and Substance-Free Program Assistant
Recovery and Substance-Free Program Assistant
Apply
Job Description:
Program Description:
The Donovan ‘59 Program for Recovery and Substance-Free Student Initiatives provides resources to support students in recovery from substance use disorders, students who would like to change their relationship to substances, students who are negatively affected by their own or others' substance use, and students who identify as substance-free for personal, medical, religious, or any other reason. The Donovan Program coordinates the Substance-Free Thematic Community at 219 Bowen Street, a weekly support group for students who are in recovery from substance use disorder, a weekly support group for students exploring harm reduction strategies, and the Lunch Bunch (a monthly meeting for faculty, staff, and graduate students in recovery) as well as aims to foster community and support for members of Brown community who are in recovery or who identify as substance-free for any reason. The Program collaborates with the SoBear Student Activities Group and Brown Addiction Medicine Club, as well as other campus partners and local community organizations to develop events relevant to the communities we serve.
Job Description:
The College, under the supervision of the Associate Dean of the College for Junior/Senior Studies and Recovery and Substance-Free Student Initiatives, is seeking a qualified graduate student interested in engaging with students in recovery or who identify as substance-free for any reason through The Donovan Program for Recovery and Substance-Free Initiatives. The Donovan Program is the oldest collegiate recovery program in the United States and helps to support students who are in recovery from substance use disorders through recovery & harm reduction support groups, enhanced academic support, advocacy, referrals, and community building.
The Recovery and Substance-Free Program Assistant (RSFP Assistant) coordinates daily function of the Substance-Free Thematic Community at 219 Bowen Street (colloquially known as Donovan House), works with the Donovan Communications Assistant to perform campus outreach and anti-stigma advocacy, and collaborates with the Dean, SoBear Student Activities Group, Brown Addiction Medicine Club, and campus partners to develop recovery and/or substance-free programming. The Substance-Free Thematic Community supports 17 students in recovery and their substance-free allies. The RSFP Assistant is responsible for working with students in the house to build a community of substance-free students and supporting their efforts to create an inclusive and welcoming campus environment for other students who choose to be substance-free. The RSFP Assistant will organize both wellness and/or community building programming for substance-free students, and help with assessment and evaluation of current climate and needs of substance-free students. Additionally, the RSFP Assistant will coordinate events and projects that enhance the Donovan Program’s offerings as a means to gain experience and mentorship in the areas of higher education administration, professional development in the areas of recovery and behavioral health, and equity and justice in the areas of recovery.
More information on the program can be found here.
Position Requirements: 
Collaborate with the Dean for Recovery/Substance-Free Student Initiatives and partners in Residential Life to administer day-to-day functioning of the Substance-Free Thematic Community as well as substance-free housing across the campus.
Participate in development of Substance-Free Thematic Community Orientation for early September and attend orientations and resource fairs.
Provide regular group check-in meetings (usually with a meal) for Substance-Free Thematic Community students.
Assess substance-free housing programs and services to determine effectiveness and collaborate on providing programmatic improvements.
Assist the Dean for Recovery/Substance-Free Student Initiatives in the development, assessment, and facilitation of programs and events that attract substance-free students to the Donovan Program for Recovery/Substance-Free Initiatives, decrease stigma surrounding addiction/recovery, and create safe and supportive spaces for students in recovery and their substance-free allies.
Assist the Donovan Communications Assistant with outreach across the University and in the RI community.
Collaborate with SoBear to develop an off-campus retreat during Spring Weekend and SAO to provide a substance-free safe space during Spring Weekend Concerts.
Participate in planning and implementation of the Second Annual Recovery and Harm Reduction Film Festival.
Occasionally participate on University committees to better support substance-free students.
Position Qualifications:
Bachelor’s Degree.
Current graduate student (in any discipline) at Brown.
Excellent communication skills both verbal and written.
Excellent organizational and planning skills and attention to detail are extremely important.
Ability to build relationships with a diverse set of students and administrators.
Ability to work independently and manage complex projects.
Interest in public health; counseling; behavioral sciences; critical addiction/recovery studies (arts/humanities); student affairs; or related area.
Ability to work some nights and weekends.
Knowledge of addiction, substance use, harm reduction, and/or recovery issues would be helpful.
Hourly Rate: $22.50/hour
Submission Guidelines:
Please submit a brief cover letter outlining your experiences and desire to take on this position as well as a resume. If you are unsure how to create these documents, please see the Center for Career Exploration’s Campus Employment page.
Please note that in order to be considered an applicant for any student job at Brown University, you must submit an application form for each position for which you believe you are qualified. Applications are not kept on file for future consideration.

Cohort Initiative Student Coordinator
Cohort Initiative Student Coordinator
Apply
Job Description:
This part-time student position will contribute to the activities of the College’s Cohort Initiative which supports undergraduate students of color in building a sense of belonging and community that complements their engagement in the Open Curriculum. This position will collaborate closely with the Senior Associate Dean for Student Belonging on student outreach and communications, programming and event planning, surveys and feedback collection, and peer support initiatives. 
The work of this position will primarily focus on developing outreach and programming efforts for undergraduate students of color. These efforts will communicate the value and possibility of engaging in a cohort learning community and assess the success of these initiatives.
Activities Include: 
Supports existing programming, including leadership workshops, weekly dinners and lunches, and off-campus trips; provides insight and suggestions for new programming initiatives.
Assists in survey administration and creating reports based on survey data at designated times throughout the year (each semester, academic year, and/or program cycle).
Contributes to the creation of communications for various co-curricular opportunities for students, including digital communications (e.g., Today at Brown postings, email invitations, social media graphics) and print material.
Assesses current communication methods/channels and provides suggestions on the best practices for reaching current students.
Forms connections with peer advisors at various campus centers; determines ways to best collaborate and leverage partnerships to inform students about co-curricular opportunities.
Supports the Senior Associate Dean with additional Cohort Initiative projects, as needed.
Qualifications Required:
Attention to detail and ability to follow through on a project from start to finish.
Excellent written and oral communication skills.
Ability to articulate the value of relationships, community, and belonging in the context of Brown’s Open Curriculum.
Demonstrated ability to support a community of diverse perspectives and cultures in an inclusive environment, as well as demonstrated success collaborating with diverse peers or colleagues.
Demonstrated experience contributing to and working toward goals for student belonging, community connection and inclusion.
Nice to Have (but not required):
Experience in on-campus student activity groups.
Experience in marketing or graphic design.
Requirements
The position will begin at the start of the Fall semester on September 1, 2025 and end in May 2026 (with the exception of university holidays and breaks; the work schedule can/will be adjusted as necessary). This role is expected to require 8-10 hours per week during the Fall and Spring semester. It is paid at $15.45 per hour. Only currently enrolled (not on leave) undergraduate Brown students are eligible to apply.

Job Description:
Job Description:
We are seeking an undergraduate Research Assistant to join our economics research team focusing on the digitization and structured analysis of historical government research project documents. This position offers hands-on experience applying computational methods to extract economic insights from archival materials.
The RA will process historical government documents using OCR and AI tools, build Python pipelines to transform unstructured text into structured datasets, clean and standardize extracted data, develop solutions for challenging document formats, document methods while maintaining organized data repositories, and collaborate with the research team on data analysis.

Job Requirements:
Strong Python programming skills, Experience with text extraction code and techniques ( including OCR technology and AI/ML strategies -- experience through courses, independent projects, or other research experiences), Attention to detail, Independent problem-solving ability.
Start Date: September 8, 2025
End Date: December 12, 2025
Hourly Rate: $18
Hours Per Week: 10 hours

Please submit a resume, unofficial transcript, and a cover letter describing your relevant coding projects and experiences.

Intramural and Club Sports Student Supervisor
Intramural and Club Sports Student Supervisor
Apply
Job Description:
The Intramural and Club Sports Student Supervisor is responsible for managing live-play during intramural events, providing feedback to Intramural Sport Student Officials in between games, providing a positive customer service experience to Intramural Sport participants, managing risk at athletic facilities during intramural and club sport events, and providing feedback to the Intramural and Club Sport Manager on how to improve the student experience in these programs.
Major Tasks:
Know and properly enforce all Athletics and Recreation policies, procedures, rules, and regulations.
Assist all student officials in enforcement of all policies and rules.
Maintain proper records of all games, including game sheets, injury reports, ejection reports and protest forms.
Determine and make final decision if playing conditions are safe to continue play.
Maintain records of all game equipment.
Review score sheets and all forms for accuracy and completeness.
Act as a first responder to all injuries at events not covered by an athletic trainer or EMS unit. In the cases with an athletic trainer or EMS unit, coordinate care with the athletic trainer/EMS and assist.
Manage the facility and event, providing customer service to athletes and spectators. Manage the crowd as needed using best judgment. Call DPS if needed.
At the end of the event, ensure club members put away all the equipment and make sure the facility is clean before leaving.
Attend supervisor and full staff meetings.
Attend all training meetings for each semester.
Be a leader at game sites and during staff trainings and meetings.
Give the intramural student officials timely, valuable, and constructive feedback.
Job Qualifications:

Graduate Student Research Assistant
Graduate Student Research Assistant
Apply
Job Description:
Job Overview:
This is an NIH-funded research study on cannabis use among young adults. This longitudinal mixed-methods (quantitative surveys and qualitative interviews) study involves cannabis-related research to be assessed during in-person and virtual research protocols. The research assistant will assist in recruitment, screening, conducting in-person and Zoom-based research sessions, participant tracking and retention, and monitoring online surveys and data.
Primary Responsibilities: 
Recruitment of young adult participants from the local community and across New England: e.g., posting online advertisements, posting flyers around the community, fielding contact attempts from interested participants, managing online and telephone screening for eligibility, and monitoring participant scheduling
Data collection and management: monitor Qualtrics survey submissions and assist with remote and in-person participant sessions; conduct regular review of data from monthly Qualtrics surveys completed to ensure compliance with all protocols
Participant monitoring:  RA will manage a participant tracking database and will maintain participant contact including corresponding with participants regularly regarding compliance, scheduling, reminders, and fielding questions
Assist with other study-related tasks including preparing study materials for implementation, programming surveys, or IRB submissions
Attend weekly team meetings
Requirements:
Currently enrolled in a graduate-level degree program
Consistent attention to detail
Displays self-initiative 
Excellent time management and organizational skills
Ability to work independently and function effectively as a team member 
Proficiency in Excel or related databases
Strong communication skills
Experience with Qualtrics, web design and programming skills preferred but not required.
Coursework in research methods or prior experience conducting research is preferred but not required.
Flexibility in work schedule is preferable, including evening hours if necessary
Work Location: In-person, potential for some remote work
Time Frame: March 2025-May 2026
Anticipated Hours per Week: 10-15 hours
Please note that students must have an I9 on file at the HR Service Center in order to be hired. This must be completed before hired into the position. Students should not be working until they are officially hired in Workday.

Job Description:
The Department of Visual Art is currently hiring students in the role of Studio Safety Monitor for the following studios, as well as substitute monitor positions:
Book Arts Studio
Darkroom
Digital Print Lab
Printmaking Studio
Painting Studio
Substitutes (all studios)
Monitors will work with Visual Art staff members to receive appropriate training and communicate status of the studios throughout the semester. Monitors are required to attend Health and Safety certified training from Brown's Department of Environmental Health and Safety
Responsibilities of Studio Safety Monitors include, but are not limited to:
Ensuring responsible, safe use of the studios by performing regular inspections of the space and reminding students to clean up after themselves;
Restocking and reorganizing supplies as advised by staff;

Additional studio specific tasks to be assigned, with additional training provided as needed. Shifts are Sunday, Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday evenings (each monitor will work one or two shifts per week, according to their availability. Opportunities to pick up additional shifts are frequent.)

Concentration

Job Description:
Project Overview 
How do states gain citizen cooperation with their agendas and programs? A vast scholarship across the social sciences has fixated on states’ use of ‘sticks’ (such as coercion, penalties for breaking the law, which include monetary fines and even imprisonment) and ‘carrots’ (for example, a range of  incentives). This ‘rational’ repertoire of tactics is certainly important but also insufficient. States across the world and through time have relied equally and arguably, even more heavily, on a vast, relatively underemphasized but potent reservoir of cultural and ideational power to persuade and gain the cooperation of their citizens. What exactly is this ‘symbolic power’? How can we operationalize it? These are the main tasks of this project. Research assistants will work closely with Prof. Prerna Singh and a graduate student manager to quantitatively test and develop a theory of compliance capacity. 
Position Overview
We are seeking a highly motivated Research Assistant (RA) to support project
Measuring State Symbolic Power: The Cultural and Ideational Components of State Capacity. This position is ideal for advanced undergraduate or master’s students with strong quantitative research skills and an interest in public policy, political economy, or development studies. The RA will assist with data collection, cleaning, and analysis, and contribute to empirical research using quantitative datasets. This role offers an opportunity to engage with ongoing research in political science and develop essential skills for conducting social science research.
Key Responsibilities
Conduct data cleaning, management, and analysis using STATA, R, or Python.
Support the creation of data visualizations, summary statistics, and reports.
Conduct literature reviews and compile relevant policy documents and datasets.
Participate in regular research meetings and discussions.
Assist in implementing econometric analysis.
Qualifications & Skills
Required:
Proficiency in STATA, R, or Python for data cleaning and analysis.
Familiarity with statistical methods for quantitative research.
Strong data management and problem-solving skills.
Ability to work independently and meet deadlines.
Preferred:
Understanding of econometric techniques (e.g., regression analysis, causal inference).
Experience working with large administrative or survey datasets.
Prior research experience in political science, economics, public policy, or a related field.
Commitment & Compensation
Wage: $18.00 hourly.
Duration: 12 weeks.
How to Apply
Interested candidates should submit:
A CV or resume highlighting relevant experience.
A brief cover letter outlining their research interests and technical skills. Please highlight past experience demonstrating proficiency in STATA, R, or Python.

2025-03-24

Brown Research Strategy Intern
Brown Research Strategy Intern
Apply
Job Description:
The Brown Research Strategy Intern is a paid internship for an advanced undergraduate, graduate student, postdoc, or medical student interested in research strategy and the development of research collaborations. This role will join the Research Strategy and Development (RSD) team in the Division of Research. The mission of RSD is to catalyze creative research by empowering individuals and teams to lead strategic research endeavors with global impact. We are open to applicants representing diverse areas of expertise in life sciences, public health, engineering and physical sciences.
The intern will work under the supervision of the Associate Director of Research Strategy. The intern will receive training in strategic planning, facilitation, and proposal development, all of which are critical skills for successful research collaborations, from inception to final publication. The intern will learn these skills by working alongside experienced professionals. As a member of the RSD team, they will help run workshops (virtual and in-person) and support proposal development for research collaborations led by Brown faculty in pursuit of federal funding. The intern will learn how to identify funding opportunities, bring together interested faculty as collaborators, and facilitate the strategy development process required for a successful federal funding proposal.
This position is intended to supplement the regular coursework, research, and teaching responsibilities of Brown graduate students and postdocs. The intern must be able to commit to the program (10 hours per week, virtual) without negatively impacting their own academic progress. PhD students and postdocs must have the consent of their advisor in order to participate. While we encourage international students to apply,  please be aware that admission into the program is contingent upon coordination with OISSS. The selected intern  must comply with guidance from the Graduate Student and/or Postdoc office as appropriate to ensure that the program aligns with their current status at Brown.
The intern will work in the following areas:
Federal Funding Proposal Development
Proposals will involve federal funding opportunities issued by agencies such as the National Institute of Health, the National Science Foundation, the Department of Energy, NASA, and, in some cases, defense agencies.
Proposal development skills include identifying funding opportunities, developing tasks lists from solicitation announcements, connecting to resources at Brown such as data management resources, facilities, and letters of commitment or collaboration from university leadership.
Collaboration Facilitation Skills
Forming and leading multi-disciplinary teams
Running efficient and engaging meetings
Project management skills using G-Suite tools
Managing diverse personalities
Promoting inclusive excellence
Strategy Development Skills
Understanding of core approaches to strategy development, which generally involve helping groups generate, develop, select and implement their ideas. 
Training in Strategic Doing, which supports teams to efficiently form collaborations, move them toward measurable outcomes, and make adjustments along the way.
Training in Appreciative Inquiry, a strengths-based, high-engagement approach to collaborative strategy development.
Qualifications
Education and Experience
Undergraduates: completed at least two years of your undergraduate program and have prior relevant professional experience.
Brown University graduate degree candidates or post-doctoral researchers - we particularly encourage applicants from STEM fields including BioMed, Public Health, Engineering, Brain Science, Digital Health, Chemistry, Physics and Computer Science.
Applicants  must have written consent from their faculty advisor (PhD candidates and Postdocs)
Competencies
Strong science/technical background
Strong writing skills, e.g. the ability to distill complex scientific concepts into broadly understandable language
Strong communication skills, including writing for lay audiences, public speaking, and graphic communication.
Ability to work independently to meet project deadlines
Commitment and availability for 10 hours per week for a minimum of one year
Enthusiasm and willingness to take on new challenges

2025-03-27

Job Description:
The Sheridan Center Academic Tutoring Program is recruiting undergraduates who are passionate about teaching and learning and feel comfortable answering questions in small group settings (~6 students). Completed the course they are applying to with a grade of A or B.
Available to work a minimum of four hours per week (on average).
Participate in training and attend tutor program meetings.
Effective communication skills.
Prior tutoring experience is not required.
Please note that we keep information on file and will only contact you if your area of expertise is needed. Interviews are ~30 minutes, and applicants should expect to teach a short 5-minute interactive lesson for the course they are applying for.

MPA Summer Sequence Graders 2025
MPA Summer Sequence Graders 2025
Apply
Job Description:
The MPA program is seeking applications for several part time Graders to support the delivery of its 2024 Summer Sequence courses in statistics and economics, which will run between June 16 - August 22, 2025. Graders will help grade class assignments (chiefly problem sets) on a part-time basis throughout the Summer Sequence. 
Candidates for the grader role should have achieved excellent performance in classes in Statistics, Econometrics, and Intermediate Microeconomics, and have familiarity with Excel. Current graduate students are preferred for this role; advanced undergraduates with equivalent academic experience may also be considered.
Graduate student graders will be paid $22.50/hour; undergraduate graders will be paid  $17.50/hour. We anticipate each position will offer 10-15 hours work per week (weekly amounts may vary based on the class schedule and assignment due dates, and the MPA program reserves the right to offer more hours to appointees, subject to their availability). It may be possible to do this work remotely. 
Application Instructions:
Applicants should include a short (150 words max) statement outlining their relevant experience, and provide an up to date resume and a copy of your internal transcript. 
Please also indicate your weekly availability during the Summer Sequence period, and to highlight any periods when you will not be available to work. 
Review of applications will begin immediately and the posting will remain open until a sufficient number of candidates have been hired. 
For questions about this posting or about your application, please email Samantha Griffin, MPA Program Manager for Operations samantha_griffin@brown.edu).

Student Research Assistant
Student Research Assistant
Apply
Job Description:
The research assistant will assist in conducting recruitment and data collection for studies conducted with adults who use cannabis and alcohol. Studies range from human laboratory studies to data collected in the natural environment. Data collection includes daily surveys completed on participants' smartphones, data collected in the laboratory in experimental drug administration sessions, and qualitative interviews completed remotely.  
Primary Responsibilities:
Participant recruitment: RA will monitor recruitment of adult alcohol and cannabis users from the community. This involves posting advertisements online and flyers around the community, fielding contact attempts from interested participants, managing screening for eligibility, and scheduling participants.  
Data management: RA will conduct regular tracking, processing, and quality assurance of data from ecological momentary assessment (EMA) surveys and Qualtrics surveys to ensure compliance with all protocols. RA will assist in coding of qualitative interviews completed in the study.
Participant follow-up: RA will correspond with participants regularly regarding compliance, scheduling, reminders, fielding questions, and meeting participants for  visits to the laboratory at CAAS.
Fund custodian: RA will track compliance and determine payments. 
Screening: RA will conduct telephone screening of participants to determine initial eligibility. 
Assist in other study related tasks as needed.
Position Requirements:
Excellent organizational and communication skills. 
Ability to work independently and as part of a team. 
Flexibility in work schedule is preferable, including evening hours if necessary 
College-level coursework in Psychology, Public Health, or related field with at least 1-year of experience preferred. 
Previous research experience through academic training or previous work experience preferred. 
Experience with Qualtrics or similar survey software preferred. 
Knowledge of computer applications, including Word, PowerPoint, Excel.
Work Location: On Campus
Anticipated Hours per Week: 10
Please note that student must complete an I-9 (or have one on file) in order to begin working. 
Recruiting Start Date:
2025-04-07

Domini Lab Research Assistant
Domini Lab Research Assistant
Apply
Job Description:
On-Campus Job Opportunity: Research Assistant Position

The 3D Information for Perception and Action Lab (directed by Prof. Fulvio Domini) is looking for a motivated undergraduate student to join our team as a research assistant. This is a paid, on-campus position for approximately 8 hours per week, with flexible scheduling.

This role offers valuable hands-on experience in human subjects research — including work with virtual reality and 3D perception studies. Responsibilities include participant recruitment and onboarding, running experiments, managing data, and attending research meetings. We’re looking for someone who is organized, communicative, and excited to learn — including programming and working with VR and motion-tracking devices.

Requirements:
• Must be authorized to work in the U.S. for on-campus employment (required for paid positions)
• Undergraduate student status
• Availability for approximately 8 hours per week
• Strong communication and organizational skills
• Responsive to communication, reliable, and responsible
 Preferred Skills:
• Experience working with human participants in a research setting
• Interest in perception, cognitive science, or related fields
• Willingness to learn programming and work with VR systems (no prior experience required)
 If you’re interested in research and enjoy working in a collaborative environment, we’d love to hear from you!

2025-04-14

Undergraduate Teaching Assistant (NEUR0010)
Undergraduate Teaching Assistant (NEUR0010)
Apply
Job Description:
Summary 
Drs. Paradiso and Stein are looking for undergraduates interested in being Teaching Assistants for NEUR0010 in the Fall of 2025. Applications are welcome from people with any concentration relevant to neuroscience. The minimum neuroscience coursework that must be completed before serving as a TA is NEUR0010, NEUR1020, and NEUR1030. If you are interested, please fill out this form. You will also need to fill out a Google Form (https://forms.gle/mpYxWu2XmitijhCCA). Applications are due by April 30 and interviews will be held during reading period. 

Much of the success of NEUR0010 is due to the brilliant energetic undergraduate TAs we are fortunate to have.  While this is a rewarding experience, teaching assistantships in NEUR0010 require a significant amount of time. This includes attendance at lectures (T/Th 1-2:20pm), a weekly TA meeting (T or Th 12:15 - 12:45pm), preparing for and co-teaching recitation sections, proctoring exams, and helping to field questions on Ed Discussion.  The number of hours you can work is capped at 9 hours per week. If you are selected, you will be expected to make a firm commitment. 
Recruiting Start Date:
2025-04-14

Biology Group Tutors (Fall 2025): 0470

Job Description:
The Sheridan Center Academic Tutoring Program is recruiting undergraduates who are passionate about teaching and learning and feel comfortable answering questions in small group settings (~6 students). Tutors facilitate small group sessions where students review weekly course learning objectives, enhance problem-solving skills, and exchange study and test-taking strategies to help deepen their understanding of material taught in class.
UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS ONLY:
Completed the course they are applying to with a grade of A or B.
Available to work a minimum of four hours per week (on average).
Participate in training and attend tutor program meetings.
Effective communication skills.
Prior tutoring experience is not required.
Please note that we keep information on file and will only contact you if your area of expertise is needed. Interviews are ~30 minutes, and applicants should expect to teach a short 5-minute interactive lesson for the course they are applying for.
Required: A completed application and the course number(s) applying to. Students should indicate the course number(s) in the "skills" section.
Compensation: $18 p/hr

SDC Gallery and Makerspace Coordinator
SDC Gallery and Makerspace Coordinator
Apply
Job Description:
Under the supervision of the SDC Assistant Director, the SDC Gallery and Makerspace Coordinator will: 
● Work with the SDC staff to continue the vision and goal of the Gallery Makerspace by managing and organizing the use of the space 
● Ensure Gallery/Makerspace supplies and materials are labeled and organized, including the organization of materials in the SDC craft closet 
● With sustainability in mind, help manage the inventory of supplies and keep track of materials needs for the makerspace 
● Plan, promote, and facilitate 1-2 programs per semester focused on the needs of the Gallery Makerspace. Past programs have included a quilting event with local artists, student artist exhibitions, scrapbooking events, collective art activities, and community conversations with a creative component 
● Support the coordination and programming of the Women’s History Month Series ● Support collaborative programming and community-building efforts with the Gender and Sexuality Peer Counselors, Disability Justice Student Initiative, The LGBTQ Center, and other centers and departments on campus 
● Work front desk staffing shifts at the SDC, 
● Assist with other SDC events and special projects as needed 
● Attend weekly SDC staff meetings 
● Attend a fall and winter all-staff training and other required trainings throughout the year 
● Complete two position reflections 
● Attend all significant SDC events and programs 
● Meet weekly for supervisory check-ins with the SDC Assistant Director.
All SDC staff members are part of a cohort of students invested in exploring issues focused on women and gender; staff members are expected to be present and participate in center activities and programs. The Gallery and Makerspace Coordinator will maintain an archive of planning documents and submit a year-end report of activities and learning goals/objectives.
Job Requirements 
Required: 
● Experience in visual and creative arts 
● Will be able to serve in position for a full academic year (Students studying away or abroad during the academic year will not be eligible for the position) 
● Interest in exploring issues around women, gender, and sexuality 
● Good conduct standing 
Preferred 
● Previous experience with coordinating/planning programs 
● Experience collaborating in groups and working with others
Hours : 8-10hrs per week
Pay: $15.45/hr
Recruiting Start Date:
2025-04-17

Event Photographer
Event Photographer
Apply
Job Description:
The Nelson Center for Entrepreneurship (NCE) seeks an up-beat, Brown University undergraduate student to capture photos and occasionally videos at  Nelson Center for Entrepreneurship events. These photos and videos will be shared primarily in the Nelson Center’s newsletter, social media page, and on occasion, shared with other outlets and individuals.
Responsibilities begin April 2025 and run through May 2025. The Event Photographer works closely with NCE staff and reports to the Student Program Manger, and the Nelson Center’s Assistant Director. 

This paid position is intended for first-year or second-year undergraduate students, although all qualified candidates should apply.
Position description
Attending and photographing events as requested; evenings and occasional weekends are required.
Share sample photos 24 hours after an event and a full photo gallery within 48-72 hours. 
Hours vary and are dependent on NCE events. The average hours for each photo shoot is 10 hours, 2-4 hours on site and 6-8 hours post processing. 
Strong applicants will possess the following qualifications
Experience in using Google Drive and photo editing software.
Comfortable communicating with peers, staff, visitors, etc.
Detail-oriented, organized, friendly, confident self-starter.
Comfortable working independently 
Ability to meet deadlines and to anticipate next steps. 
Reliable and flexible with varied schedule.
Demonstrated knowledge of design software, such as Canva, Figma, Adobe Spark. Knowledge of the Adobe visual design suite, Photoshop, Illustrator, InDesign a plus.
Knowledge of or willingness to learn new communication and platforms (Google Forms, Slack, Notion, Mailchimp, and Wordpress).
Qualifications & interests that are a plus, but not required
A current Brown undergraduate, preference for a first-year or sophomore who would be able to continue as an event photographer in future academic years, although all candidates will be considered. We are unable to pay non-Brown students at this time. 
An interest in and knowledge of business and entrepreneurship is a plus but not required.
Familiarity with entrepreneurship is not required but a plus. (entrepreneurially minded)! 
Recruiting Start Date:
2025-04-18

Job Description:
Under the supervision of the SDC Assistant Director, the Graphic Design Coordinators will: 
● Create visual imagery and graphics for the Sarah Doyle Center’s programs, building signage, and center swag (e.g., SDC branded stickers and bookmarks) 
● Create and design posters and graphics for social media to advertise upcoming events as well as physical copies to be distributed across campus 
● Design the annual Women’s History Month Calendar that displays all of the events for the month-long programming series 
● Collaborate with the Digital Communication Coordinator to develop a media and publicity strategy 
● Create event publicity and marketing materials for the SDC Graduate Student Coordinator, the Disability Justice Student Initiative, and the Gender and Sexuality Peer Counselors. 
● Work a minimum of 8 hrs/week of front desk staffing shifts at the SDC ● Assist with other SDC events and special projects as needed 
● Attend 1/hr weekly SDC staff meetings 
● Attend a fall and winter all-staff training and other required trainings throughout the year 
● Submit a year-end report of learning goals and objectives 
● Attend all significant SDC events and programs 
● Meet weekly with SDC Assistant Director and co-coordinator for supervisory check-ins 
All SDC staff members are part of a cohort of students invested in exploring issues focused on women and gender; staff members are expected to be present and participate in center activities and programs. The Graphic Design Coordinators will maintain an archive of graphics and submit a year-end report of earning goals/objectives.
