Required: 
● Good communication skills, both verbal and written 
● Knowledge of Adobe InDesign, Photoshop, Illustrator, and/or other graphic design software

● Interest in exploring issues around women, gender, and sexuality

Students from all gender identities are encouraged to apply. The SDC seeks to build a diverse and inclusive community. We welcome applicants from all concentrations. Student staffers must be in Good Conduct Standing for the duration of their role.

The Vietnamese Program at Brown University seeks two enthusiastic, dedicated undergraduate teaching assistants to support our language instruction. As a teaching assistant, you can engage with undergraduates, facilitate tutorial sessions, lead language tables, and help develop teaching materials. Here are the details:
Qualifications:
We welcome applications from both Vietnamese native speakers and non-native speakers who have completed advanced Vietnamese courses.
Essential requirements include excellent pronunciation, solid conversational skills at the intermediate level, and a passion for the Vietnamese language and culture.
Responsibilities:
Conduct weekly tutorial sessions for students in the Vietnamese classes. (2 hr/week)
Lead a language table twice a month, fostering language practice and cultural exchange. (2-hour prep, 2-hour live sessions/month)
[1 TA] Collaborate with the Vietnamese Program faculty (Cô Trang) to develop teaching materials to enhance student learning experiences. (1 hr/week)
[1 TA] Maintain the website, the Instagram page, and the Facebook page of Brown’s Vietnamese program. (1 hr/week)
Work Schedule:
The position requires a commitment of 3-4 hours per week.
The position begins during the second week (Sep 10, 2025) and concludes by the end of the Reading Period (Dec 6, 2025).
Please include a short essay based on the following prompts in the job documents, with your cover letter.

ENGN0030 - UTA - Wearable Sensors - Gray Laderer
ENGN0030 - UTA - Wearable Sensors - Gray Laderer
Apply
Job Description:
ENGN 0030: Introduction to Engineering is a course taken by the majority of incoming students at Brown that provides the foundation for further study in engineering. We are seeking Undergraduate Teaching Assistants (UTAs) with various academic and engineering backgrounds to assist with the needs of this module.

The Wearable Sensors Module, led by Professor Gray, provides ENGN 0030 students with an introduction to building sensors with Arduino technology, collecting real-world data, and analyzing that data with MATLAB. This module contains elements of Biomedical, Electrical, Mechanical, Computer, Design, and Environmental engineering. Specifically, UTAs will help students study the technology and applications of wearable electronics, provide hands-on assistance in the building and customization of sensors (using Arduino and CAD), and provide assistance in analyzing the data using MATLAB principles.

UTA’s Responsibilities May Include:
- Be available to work up to 6 hours per week
- Facilitate presentations to small groups and direct students through problems
- Prepare weekly section material
- Attend weekly ENGN 0030 meetings
- Monitor Ed Discussion online platform
- Maintain timely communication with the ENGN 0030 team
- Work closely with Professor Gray and other TAs to ensure the success of students
- Evaluate weekly problem set submissions
- Hold office hours and review sessions

Potential roles for Head TA’s are also available, where in addition to the above responsibilities, Head TA’s will need to mediate communication between the professors and other Wearable Module TAs, as well as disseminate information from Professors Gray and/or Laderer to the TA team. Please indicate in your application if you’d like to be considered for a Head TA position. These positions may be up to 10 hours per week. 
Position Qualifications
Be available for virtual training in late August and an in-person session on Tuesday 9/2.
- Must be in good academic standing at Brown University.
- Candidates must have taken ENGN 0030 or ENGN 0032 before.

This position is from August 18, 2025 through December 31, 2025, working six hours weekly. 
**MUST COMPLETE I-9 TO BE AUTHORIZED TO WORK**

German Studies Undergraduate Language Tutor

Job Description:
German Studies is hiring an undergraduate language tutor for Fall 2025 (with the possibility of extension for spring 2026). We are looking for someone to hold conversation practice with undergraduates enrolled in beginning and intermediate German classes. Do you speak German at an advanced level? Do you know how to keep a conversation in German going? Do you like helping other students learn more about German language and culture? Please apply!
Responsibilities include (1) meeting with students in-person on a weekly basis for conversational practice, (2) coordinating relevant topics and materials with faculty and (3) scheduling and tracking attendance.
The successful candidate will fulfill one or more of the following requirements: completed at least one 1000-level course conducted in German, spent a summer or semester or more studying, living or interning in a German-speaking country, or be a native or near-native speaker of German.
Hourly wage:  $15.00/hr
Hours:  5 hours per week

Job Description:
ENGN 0030: Introduction to Engineering is a course taken by the majority of incoming students at Brown that provides the foundation for further study in engineering. This module provides a foundation in product design. Students will be asked to develop a working prototyping for a near future scenario over the course of the module. UTAs will support students throughout the design process, including support with CAD, 3D printing, and Arduinos.

ENGN0090 - UTA - Chaltas
ENGN0090 - UTA - Chaltas
Apply
Job Description:
"The ENGN 90/900 Teaching Assistant Role

Section meetings led by student TAs have been an important part of the ENGN 0090 & ENGN 0900 student experience for decades. Over the last 40+ years, thousands of TAs have offered their time to lead small group discussions where every student can share their analysis, insights and recommendations for section cases. Section meetings help students build skills and confidence in sharing their perspective in a small group environment.

This document shares the expectations for TAs. We have developed the guidelines and expectations below to help create a consistently excellent section experience for students. As you consider serving as a TA, think about how the points below serve as your commitment to the class and the students.

Note that all TAs must have taken ENGN 90/900 in the past and must complete the separate Google form application that will be sent to all interested and qualified candidates. Undergraduate Head TAs and instructors will make final hiring decisions.

As a TA for ENGN 0090 and/or ENGN 0900, you are expected to:
• Prepare for weekly sections by re-reading cases, reviewing TA discussion guides, and the your own notes from your time as a student in the class.
• Hold weekly section meetings to discuss the section cases, encouraging all students to actively participate. Meet with students outside section meetings to make up missed sections.
• In the event that a section is not held in a week, make up the case discussion on another day.
• Support students throughout the semester, enabling them to enjoy the learning process. Set up time to meet with students who cannot make section.
• Grade 40-50 section papers per semester following provided rubric (specific number TBD pending both course enrollment and number of TAs).
• Compile section participation grades (following provided rubric) and send to head TAs and Professor Chaltas at end of semester (mid-December ENGN 0090 and mid-May for ENGN 0900). Specific due date will be provided.
• Communicate weekly with students in section, as the first line in making sure they’re comprehending material and staying on track.
• Proactively share any insights or issues regarding individual students or the course overall or with the head TAs and Professor Chaltas.

We estimate TAs will work a total of ~30 hours during the semester: 1-2 hours per week on section prep leading 10 section meetings with additional hours for section paper grading, meeting with students and general administration

Applicants must complete a separate online application and be selected by Professor. 
Position Qualifications:

ENGN0030 - UTA: Wireless Module - Mittleman Laderer

Job Description:
ENGN 0030: Introduction to Engineering is a course taken by the majority of incoming students at Brown that provides the foundation for further study in engineering. We are seeking Undergraduate Teaching Assistants (UTAs) with various academic and engineering backgrounds to assist with the needs of this module.

The Wireless Module, led by Professor Mittleman, provides ENGN 0030 students with an introduction to wireless technology, covering fields including Electrical Engineering and Physics. UTAs will support students in learning the fundamentals of wireless data links by explaining electromagnetic waves and their role in communication, guiding them through electric and magnetic field concepts, teaching vector properties and polarization of EM waves, and exploring the principles and applications of antennas, radiation patterns, and modulation techniques through practical examples and computational exercises.

UTA’s Responsibilities May Include:
- Be available to work an average of 5 hours per week
- Facilitate presentations to small groups and direct students through problems
- Prepare weekly section material
- Attend weekly ENGN 0030 meetings
- Monitor Ed Discussion online platform
- Maintain timely communication with the ENGN 0030 team
- Work closely with Professor Mittleman and other TAs to ensure the success of students
- Evaluate weekly problem set submissions
- Hold office hours and review sessions

Potential roles for a Head TA is also available, where in addition to the above responsibilities, Head TA will need to mediate communication between the professors and other Wireless Module TAs, as well as disseminate information from Professors Mittleman and/or Laderer to the TA team. Please indicate in your application if you’d like to be considered for a Head TA position.

Job Description:
ENGN 0030: Introduction to Engineering is a course taken by the majority of incoming students at Brown that provides the foundation for further study in engineering. We are seeking Undergraduate Teaching Assistants (UTAs) with various academic and engineering backgrounds to assist with the needs of this module.

The Battery Module, led by Professor Qi, provides ENGN 0030 students with an introduction to batteries, covering fields including Electrical, Materials, Design, and Chemical engineering. UTAs will assist students in applying multidisciplinary engineering concepts, solving real-world problems with mathematical and scientific principles in a team setting, learning about different kinds of batteries and their applications, and understanding the relevance of engineering education to their future careers and their impact on the world. UTAs will assist in the preparation of laboratory materials and testing of the laboratory procedures (chemistry lab skills). UTAs will also help the students learn basic MATLAB programming with tools such as loops, subroutines, plotting, optimization, and passing variables.

UTA’s Responsibilities May Include:
- Be available to work up to 5 hours per week (averaged through the semester)
- Facilitate presentations to small groups and direct students through problems
- Grade homework
- Attend weekly ENGN 0030 meetings
- Monitor Ed Discussion online platform
- Maintain timely communication with the ENGN 0030 team
- Work closely with Professor Qi and other TAs to ensure the success of students
- Evaluate weekly problem set submissions
- Hold office hours and review sessions

Please indicate in your application if you’d like to be considered for a Head TA position. This position may be 10 hours per week (maximum).

Job Description:
Job title:
Student Research Assistant
Job Overview (2-3 sentences that summarize the work)::
This Research Assistant (RA) will support a study of bystander behavior in young adults that is focused on reducing sexual violence risk in alcohol contexts. RA activities involve participant recruitment and communication; participant tracking and retention, reviewing data quality and managing datafiles, managing participant payments, documenting project procedures, programming screening surveys and assessment batteries, review of relevant literature, and supporting investigator research needs.
Primary Responsibilities (Include a bulleted list)::
-Participant recruitment, scheduling and conducting study sessions
-Programming surveys and documenting assessment batteries and procedures 
-Assisting with assembly of materials for IRB modifications, manuscript and presentation preparation, and progress reports.
Requirements (i.e. customer service experience; strong attention to detail; enthusiasm etc.)::
• Excellent oral and written communication skills
• Strong organizational skills and attention to detail
• Ability to multitask and prioritize effort to meet project goals
• Openness to and keen interest in learning new skills
• Willingness and ability to support and promote a diverse and inclusive campus community
Position requires evening and weekend availability to meet participant scheduling needs for study sessions

Writing Associate
Writing Associate
Apply
Job Description:
The  Sheridan  Center  for  Teaching  and  Learning  invites  applications  for  several  Writing 
Associate  positions  for  the  upcoming  academic  year.  Writing Associates are current Brown University  graduate  students  who  support  writers  across  a  wide  range  of  disciplines  and academic  stages—including  pre-college,  undergraduate,  and  graduate  students,  as  well  as alumni and staff—through individualized, 50-minute consultations offered both in person and online. 

More than a tutoring role, the position of Writing Associate is designed to foster pedagogical 
development. Associates receive structured training in evidence-based, inclusive, and anti-racist approaches to writing pedagogy, and participate in monthly professional development sessions aimed  at  cultivating  reflective,  learner-centered  practice.  Prior  experience  with  these frameworks  is  not  required,  but  a  demonstrated  commitment  to  teaching,  learning,  and linguistic diversity is essential. 

Position Details: 
●  Associates work one or two 3-hour shifts per week. 
●  Associates attend one professional development meeting per month. 
●  Optional  opportunities  are available to design and lead writing workshops in Brown 
courses. 
●  This is an exempt, hourly position at $25/hour. 
●  Most associates work fewer than 10 hours per week. 

All  current  Brown  graduate  students  are  encouraged  to  apply, including graduate students whose experiences and identities have been historically underrepresented in higher education, including (but not limited to) students who identify as African American/Black, Latine/Latinx, Native American, Alaskan Native, Pacific Islander, Southeast Asian, LGBTQ+, neurodivergent, and  first-generation  college  graduates.  International  students  on  F-1  visas  are  strongly encouraged  to  contact  Dr.  Charlie  Carroll  (charles_carroll@brown.edu)  before  applying  to determine eligibility for this position. 

Application Instructions: 
Please submit a single PDF via WorkDay containing: 
●  A cover letter (maximum 1 page) outlining your interest in the position and relevant 
qualifications. 
●  A current CV. 
●  A writing sample of at least 10 pages, in any genre (e.g., academic writing, creative writing, nonfiction).

Apply by June 27 for priority consideration.

Summer Admission Ambassador
Summer Admission Ambassador
Apply
Job Description:
This position is for Summer 2025. Preference will be given to candidates who can work 30 hours per week or more. Students are limited to 40 hours per week.. Part-time candidates must be available to work 15-20 hours per week. Shifts are 8 am - 12 pm and 12 pm - 4pm, Monday - Friday. The application deadline is May 15, 2025. 
On Campus Job Opportunity 
Share your love of Brown as a Campus Tour Guide for the summer! Tour guides represent the University at large while sharing their own perspectives and stories of the Brown student experience. Tour guides are expected to give 60-70 minute walking tours to students, families, alumni, and school groups. Guides will also serve on panels, conduct presentations, and may work at the Campus Center front desk. 
Additional responsibilities may include checking in and welcoming visitors, attending required and optional training sessions, staying up to date with admission tour materials and university information and facts, hosting casual chats with prospective students, monitoring the askastudent@brown.edu email account, and participating in projects involving social media and video. 
Job Requirements: 
Tour guides must be reliable, consistent, punctual, sociable, quick on their feet, and knowledgeable about the Brown undergraduate experience, campus, and curriculum. Tour guides should be willing to learn more about Brown’s campus, its history, and student opportunities. One of the most important job requirements is that tour guides must be passionate about Brown and excited to share their experiences with prospective students. This position requires teamwork and flexibility as well. 
Excellent interpersonal and communication skills are a must, including a strong public speaking 
ability. Tour guides must be able to engage with all types of visitors, including but not limited to: prospective students, prospective student-athletes, parents, alumni, faculty and staff, special visitors. Tour guides should be prepared to lead tours in a variety of weather conditions, including rain, wind, heat etc.. Tour guides must also be able to positively and authentically represent the Brown student experience in alignment with the Office of College Admission.

Job Description:
Qualifications:
Undergraduate Teaching Assistant (UTA) and Head Teaching Assistant (HTA) positions are open to current Brown University undergraduates. Applicants must have successfully completed the course or an advanced equivalent, earning an A grade. For instance, for APMA 1650, completion of APMA 1655 is also fine. Your employment will be subject to transcript verification and contingent on you receiving an A. Reliability, meeting deadlines, and keeping student information confidential are to be expected.
Job Description:
Responsibilities may include: holding office hours, leading problem-solving sessions, helping grade homework, quizzes, and exams, helping provide answer keys for homework sets, being active on the course discussion platform, and proctoring exams (only if the instructor or another GTA is also present). In addition, HTA responsibilities may include assigning who grades which problem on the homework and exams, serving as a liaison between the UTAs and the instructor, and forwarding student complaints to the instructor. The typical time commitment is about 6-7 hours per week, with a maximum of 8 hours, unless visa restrictions apply.
Applications are invited for the following APMA courses for Fall 2025:
APMA 160, 260, 350, 355, 360, 650, 1000, 1080, 1170, 1210, 1650, 1655, 1690, 1710, 1860
Preference will be given to students open to TA-ing courses other than 350, 360, 1650, 1655.

GYN/GU Exam Teaching Assistant
GYN/GU Exam Teaching Assistant
Apply
Job Description:
What is a GYN/GU Teaching Assistant?
The GYN/GU Exam Teaching Assistant is responsible for instructing second year medical students in gynecological and the genitourinary exams. The initial instruction on physical examination is conducted using pelvic, breast, and rectal simulation models before students interact with GYN/GU Standardized Patients. During the hands-on examination portion, the Teaching Assistant first demonstrates the exam, and then supervises each student as they practice with the Gynecologic Teaching Assistant (GYN SPs). Throughout the session, the TA offers feedback and guidance. 
Will I have any training prior to teaching these exams?

Yes! We understand that these are sensitive exams, and we want you to be prepared! You will arrive at 4:15 and attend a 30-45 minute educational session on the GYN/GU exams with our colleagues in the Nurse/Midwifery program at Women & Infants hospital, so you know how to teach these exams.
Sessions run from 4:15-8pm on Thursdays, (9/11, 9/18, 9/25, 10/9, 10/23). 
Please note which sessions you can attend on Workday. We recommend a commitment of at least 2 of the 5 sessions for continuity of education. 
GYN/GU Lead Teaching Assistant:

In addition to the responsibilities of the GYN/GU Exam Teaching Assistant, Lead TA will develop and deliver an introductory lecture to second year students before practicing the gynecological and genitourinary exams. The Lead TA will be a resource for the other Student Teaching Assistants and help provide an orientation to the teaching assistants prior to the session. 
Lead TAs should be available for each of the scheduled five sessions and will assist with coordinating details prior to each session. 
*Please note, students who receive a monthly stipend from Brown are ineligible to apply for either position*

2025-06-16

The Shift Supervisor provides on shift crew management and patient care to complement and support the BEMS ambulance crew operations. Responsibilities include provision of emergency care according to scope of practice, resource management, crew management, on shift training or special details, confidential reporting and notifications, and highly specialized vehicle operations and accountability.

Job Description:
The Ambulance EMT works designated shifts during non-academic periods when on duty status replaces on shift status of BEMS student staff. On shift staff complete clinical education shifts as part of their volunteer hours and progression training at Brown EMS, while on duty staff carry a higher degree of shift management responsibility and reallocate training time to operational duties in addition to patient care.  New recruits are not eligible for the Ambulance EMT position until they have successfully completed their recruitment progression training, including all Professional and Core Competency modules and licensing requirements.

Completion of the BEMS New Recruit Progression Training semester

The Sheridan Center Academic Tutoring Program is recruiting undergraduates who are passionate about teaching and learning and feel comfortable answering questions in small group settings (~6 students). IAPA 0700 Political Economy of Hard Policy Problems - Professor Mark Blyth
IAPA 0700 Political Economy of Hard Policy Problems - Professor Mark Blyth
Apply
Job Description:
Instructor Professor Mark Blyth
Class Schedule Mon, Wed, Fri 10-10:50
Course Description
This class tackles some of the “hard problems” that governments and global firms routinely face. That is, while governments are cajoled and called upon to produce economic growth, do something about economic inequality and social mobility, and improve the life chances of citizens through purposive action, actually delivering these things is incredibly hard. Likewise firms are supposed to police their supply chains, decarbonize their operations, raise their wages, and pay more taxes, all at once. These areas constitute ‘hard problems’ for two main reasons. Economically, we don’t really have much of a clue about how to do many of these things. Politically, there are powerful interests and entrenched ideas out there that want to keep things just as they are.
Hourly rate  $22.50
Estimated hours: 10-15/week
Start Date 8/15/2025
Graduate/Masters Level Graders will support student learning in classes by:
grading student assignments;
holding office hours to address student questions about assignments.

IAPA 1201D Social Entrepreneurship - Professor Bill Allen

Job Description:
Course IAPA 1201D Social Entrepreneurship
Instructor Professor Bill Allen
Class Schedule Tuesdays & Thursdays 1:00-2:20
Course Description
Social Entrepreneurship, engages students in the process of exploring significant global problems and developing innovative solutions that drive transformative social change. The course helps students understand the strategies that social entrepreneurs employ to tackle complex and entrenched social problems with transformative approaches that work and impact systems. Students will learn about real organizations and interact with entrepreneurs leading this work. Case studies, complemented by articles and guest speakers, will show different approaches to social entrepreneurship and illustrate the strengths and weaknesses of various models and strategies.
Hourly rate  $22.50
Estimated hours: 10-15/week
Start Date 8/15/2025

Student Research Intern
Student Research Intern
Apply
Job Description:
We are seeking a detail-oriented and self-motivated student worker to assist with finalizing and preparing a digital timeline on Jewish history at Brown for publication. The position will primarily involve identifying, verifying, and citing sources for historical facts and images included in the timeline. The student will collaborate with staff and may consult University Archives and library materials to ensure accurate and complete documentation.
Responsibilities:
Review and cross-reference existing timeline content with primary and secondary sources
Provide proper citations for historical events and images
Track and organize source information in a clear, accessible format
Communicate progress regularly with project team members
Qualifications:
Strong research and writing skills
Familiarity with library and archival resources preferred
Ability to work independently and meet deadlines
Benefits:
Gain hands-on research experience working with historical materials, archives, and digital tools.
Contribute to a meaningful campus project that highlights and preserves the history of Jewish life at Brown.
Strengthen professional skills in project management, sourcing, and academic citation, valuable for future academic or editorial work.
Hours:
This role will require approximately 10–15 hours of work, with flexible scheduling. Ideally, all work will be completed by the end of June 2025. These hours can be worked remotely from a location in the US.
To apply, please submit your resume and a brief cover letter.

Job Description:
Title - Enrollment Graduate Assistant
Rate - $20/hr
Term - June 2025 through December 2025
Time Commitment - 8-12 hours per week with a maximum of 15 hours per week
Hiring Manager - Nathan Rush, Associate Director of Masters Admissions Systems
Work Arrangement - Hybrid with one half-day (Monday-Thursday preferred) at the School of Professional Studies, 225 Dyer
The Enrollment Graduate Assistant will support the School of Professional Studies Enrollment team with administrative duties pertaining to admission and recruitment of Master’s students to Brown University. Tasks may include cleanup of large datasets according to established parameters, processing applicant materials (e.g. transcripts, test scores), and updating presentation slides. 
The incumbent will also be an ambassador for Brown’s Master’s programs, including, but not limited to serving as a panelist for virtual information sessions, assisting with in-person on-campus events (Fifth-Year Fair), and communicating with prospective students via email.
This position requires the use of Google Suite, Microsoft Excel, Zoom, and the Technolutions Slate CRM to complete the above tasks.
Requirements:
Must be a current Brown Master’s student
Diligent attention to detail
Professionalism in working with staff, faculty, administrators, and prospective students
Ability to balance and prioritize multiple projects
Completion of Protecting Brown’s Information (PBI) module in Workday
Own/have access to a laptop (PC or Mac)

View Job Posting Details
Asian Heritage Series Programmer
Asian Heritage Series Programmer
Apply
Job Description:
Organization Summary: Visualize. Vocalize. Mobilize. The Brown Center for Students of Color (BCSC) serves as a gathering place for communities of color. Students are encouraged to build meaningful relationships across differences, develop racial and ethnic consciousness, and enact change at Brown and beyond. The BCSC advances the University’s mission of educating and preparing students to discharge the offices of life with usefulness and reputation by empowering students of color, cultivating leadership, facilitating critical reflection, fostering informed action, and promoting social justice. 
Section 3: Major Responsibilities 
The primary role of the Asian Heritage Series programmer involves coordinating and programming. The Asian Heritage Series, with a focus on Asian/ Asian American, South Asian and Southeast Asian Identity. In order to facilitate communication and schedule events effectively, the programmer(s) must work closely with the Asian American Student Association (AASA), South Asian Students Association (SASA), and all other student organizations relating to Asian/Asian American students on campus. 
Major Responsibilities: 
On-Campus and Community Outreach to Organizations (70%) 
● Communicate on a weekly basis with student organizations focused on Asian/Asian American diaspora identity, programming, community building, and other topics impacting Asian communities 
● Conduct outreach and maintain relationships that foster collaborations with external organizations in the Providence community 
● Maintain and update contact information and listserv to ensure effective communication 
Asian Heritage Series Programming and Execution (20%) 
● attend a mandatory Fall Heritage Series training. 
● attend mandatory monthly meetings with all BCSC student staffers. 
● program at least one faculty engagement event.
● reach out to non-Asian/Asian American student organizations in order to inquire about the possibility of collaboration in event planning. 
● planning of the series a semester in advance to ensure timely programming. ● creation of a planning google document to help with future event planning. ● recruit volunteers for each event to support with set up, check-ins and breakdowns ● organizing and overseeing the execution of the programmer’s projects under the supervision of the BCSC Initiatives Program Coordinator Anne Marie Ponte 
● providing support to the supervisor recruitment process. 
● Will assist at events, specifically set up, and break down, update files into google folders, create each event feedback form data, maintain logistics docs in folders for archive purposes. 
Budgetary and Fiscal Responsibilities (10%) 
● Manage funds through BCSC and launch fundraising efforts involving student organizations, departments, and centers. 
● Work with BCSC Program Coordinator/supervisor to maintain event expenses within the set program budget. 
● Follow-up with co-sponsoring organizations to ensure timely transfer of fundraising pledges. 
Section 4: Time Commitment 
BCSC Asian Heritage series work on average (8-10) hours per week, in the fall and spring semesters. Will not be expected to work during the reading period and finals. 
Section 5: Required Availability 
Fall and spring semester, excluding reading period and finals. 
Programmers are required to meet for: 
● All Heritage Series programmer staff orientation (1st half of September) ● All BCSC student staff Orientation (early fall) 
● Weekly Asian Heritage Series staff meeting with supervisor (1 hour) ● All Monthly BCSC Heritage Series Staff Meetings (up to 1 hour) 
Section 6: Job Qualifications and Remuneration 
Job Qualifications 
● Will be able to serve in the position for a full academic year. Students studying away or abroad during the academic year will not be eligible for the position 
● Must be an undergraduate student at Brown University in good academic standing. ● Great time management skills
● Maintain professional demeanor 
● Effective written and verbal communication skills 
● Ability to work independently and efficiently in a busy environment 
● Interest in promoting campus awareness about diversity issues and the mission of the BCSC ● Detail-oriented 
● Strong organizational and communication skills 
● Undergraduate student in good academic and judicial standing 
● Familiarity and knowledge of issues relevant and of interest to Asian American students at Brown ● Capacity for humility, confidence, vulnerability, and empathy 
● Lived experience or strong, nuanced awareness of race and racial justice ● Ability to be creative problem-solvers flexible, adaptable, and able work within ambiguity 
● Comfortable working as part of a team 
● Possess an understanding of group dynamics and basic conflict management skills Section 7: How to Apply 
How to Apply: To apply for the position, please visit the workday, job number #XXXX submit an updated resume and a short summary/cover letter as to why you're interested in the position? 
Applications are due on Thursday, July 31, 2025 11:59 PM 
Contact Information: Email: Anne_Ponte@brown.edu Phone: (401-863-5169)
Recruiting Start Date:
2025-06-05

● reach out to non-Native student organizations in order to inquire about the possibility of collaboration in event planning.
● planning of the series a semester in advance to ensure timely programming. ● creation of a planning google document to help with future event planning. 
● recruit volunteers for each event to support with set up, check-ins and breakdowns ● organizing and overseeing the execution of the programmer’s projects under the supervision of the BCSC Initiatives Program Coordinator/supervisor Anne Marie Ponte 
● providing support to the supervisor recruitment process. 
● Will assist at events, specifically set up, and break down, update files into google folders, create each event feedback form data, maintain logistics docs in folders for archive purposes. 
Budgetary and Fiscal Responsibilities (10%) 
● Manage funds through BCSC and launch fundraising efforts involving student organizations, departments, and centers. 
● Work with BCSC Program Coordinator/supervisor to maintain event expenses within the set program budget. 
● Follow-up with co-sponsoring organizations to ensure timely transfer of fundraising pledges. 
Section 4: Time Commitment 
BCSC Native Heritage Series programmers work on average (8-10) hours per week, in the fall and spring semesters. Will not be expected to work during the reading period and finals. 
Section 5: Required Availability 
Fall and spring semester, excluding shopping period, reading period, and finals. 
Programmers are required to meet for: 
● All Heritage Series programmer staff orientation (1st half of September) ● All BCSC student staff Orientation (early fall) 
● Weekly Native Heritage Series staff meeting with supervisor (1 hour) ● All Monthly BCSC Heritage Series Staff Meetings (up to 1 hour) 
Section 6: Job Qualifications and Remuneration 
Job Qualifications 
● Will be able to serve in the position for a full academic year. Students studying away or abroad during the academic year will not be eligible for the position 
● Must be an undergraduate student at Brown University in good academic standing. ● Great time management skills 
● Maintain professional demeanor
● Effective written and verbal communication skills 
● Ability to work independently and efficiently in a busy environment 
● Interest in promoting campus awareness about diversity issues and the mission of the BCSC ● Detail-oriented 
● Strong organizational and communication skills 
● Undergraduate student in good academic and judicial standing 
● Familiarity and knowledge of issues relevant and of interest to Native students at Brown ● Capacity for humility, confidence, vulnerability, and empathy 
● Lived experience or strong, nuanced awareness of race and racial justice ● Ability to be creative problem-solvers flexible, adaptable, and able work within ambiguity 
● Comfortable working as part of a team 
● Possess an understanding of group dynamics and basic conflict management skills Section 7: How to Apply

Undergraduate Research Assistant — North Burial Ground Documentation Project
Undergraduate Research Assistant — North Burial Ground Documentation Project
Apply
Job Description:
Undergraduate research assistants for the North Burial Ground Documentation Project will assist PIs Professor Rivera Prince and Annalisa Heppner (NBG Director) to collect, digitize, transcribe, enter data collected from tombstones and written records at Providence’s North Burial Ground. Undergraduate research assistants may also do archival research regarding NBG and those buried at the cemetery.
Specific tasks may include:
 Data collection from tombstones
 Data collection from written records
 Archival and literature searches to deepen our understanding of NBG and those
buried at the cemetery
Qualifications
Required:
o At least 3 months experience working in historic cemeteries.
o Intermediate/advanced skills in Google Sheets and Google Forms
o Excellent written and oral communication skills
o Capacity and commitment to maintain high standards for data quality and
accuracy
o Ability to read cursive
Preferred
o Ability to work independently and collaboratively
o Experience with R programming language
Requirements
This position will begin in June 2025, and end in August 2025. If mutually agreed,
there is a possibility for an extension through the Spring until May 2025.
The role is expected to take up to 10 hours per week. Hours need to be worked
between 8 am and 4 pm, Monday to Saturday, due to the cemetery’s schedule.
Data collection will occur in the field at North Burial Ground.
Students must be enrolled as an undergraduate student (in any program/year) at
Brown University for the Fall 2024 semester.
Apply
Please submit a cover letter and resume in Workday.
If you have questions about the position, please contact Professor Rivera Prince
at jordi_rivera_prince@brown.edu.

Undergraduate Research Assistant for Professor Faudree
Undergraduate Research Assistant for Professor Faudree
Apply
Job Description:
Research Assistant to Professor Paja Faudree, Department of Anthropology. I am seeking at least two Research Assistants who will assist with my current research projects as well as associated administrative tasks. These projects include publications surrounding the following themes: global trade and pharmaceutical research involving psychedelic plants, particularly those that originated in Indigenous communities from the Americas; language, politics, inequality, and discrimination; language, medicine, (mis-)communication, and medical translation; indigenous language activism, digital media, and climate change; and the mathematician Paul Erdös and his large network of collaborators and caretakers.  Assistance with various aspects of the research process will primarily involve general qualitative methods based on interviews, participant observation, and media analysis, but I am also interested in applicants with either specialized skills in these areas (e.g., experience conducting research on social media) or with skills conducting forms of quantitative research. I have a strong interest in RAs with native proficiency in Spanish (and/or any Indigenous languages of the Americas), although those who are not native speakers of Spanish or who have no Spanish abilities are also encouraged to apply. In addition, I am potentially interested in the analysis of media in languages other than English, so applicants with fluency in other languages should make those abilities known. The start date is flexible, but ideally as soon as possible. Hours and location are flexible as well. Pay is negotiable, but commensurate with similar RA positions at Brown and with the experience and skills of the applicant. If interested, please apply in Workday and submit a letter of application indicating interest in the position, experience, skills, availability, and any other information you feel is relevant. Please also include a copy of your CV.

2025-06-01

Student Research Assistant
Student Research Assistant
Apply
Job Description:
 Under the supervision of the leadership team (i.e. Principal Investigator, Project Director, and Project Manager), the Research Assistant (RA) position is a hybrid-eligible role. The RA provides recruitment, enrollment, and data collection support with the ongoing implementation of randomized control trials to test behavioral interventions targeting HIV prevention and treatment; sexual and gender minority health; and substance use among diverse populations such as sex workers and sexual minority men. The candidate must possess a willingness and ability to support and promote a diverse and inclusive campus community. 
The FRESH lab is currently looking to hire 1-2 enthusiastic student RAs to assist with ongoing research studies. Specifically, student RAs will assist the study Investigators and other lab members with research activities, including but not limited to: participant recruitment and community partner engagement; semi-structured qualitative interviews, transcription and coding; basic statistical data analysis; manuscript development, including literature review, and facilitating manuscript (re)submissions; and day-to-day study coordination, such as participant communications and scheduling participant assessments.
The student may also carve out an interest in one area to investigate for their thesis work, contribute to manuscript(s) as a co-author, present their work in academic conferences, with the understanding that the responsibilities of authorship (first or co-) may extend beyond the paid RA activities. For more information on the FRESH lab and our ongoing research studies, visit us HERE.

Job Description:
Job Description: CH330 undergraduate TAs will be expected to:
Lead a 1-hour group problem solving session (GPS) primarily in-person, but also potentially remotely, once per week. Students will help their peers through homework problems and GPS packets; 
Maintain a 1-hour per week office hour scheduled at their convenience for CH330 students to attend to have any of their additional questions addressed; 
Attend weekly check-ins and trainings led by Prof. Church for roughly 1-hour per week; 
Spend 1-2 hours per week preparing to lead their GPS sessions and reviewing the relevant material; 
In some cases, organize and lead additional review sessions for students struggling with the material or before exams. Depending upon the case, this could amount to an additional 1-hour per week of work. 
Contribute to weekly, TA-driven problem packets that can be used in TA-led help sessions and GPS. 
This amounts to an average commitment of 4-5 hours per week. Beyond these explicit tasks, students will be expected to regularly read and answer pertinent emails, and maintain communication with Prof. Rubenstein regarding the class via email, Canvas, and Slack.
Prerequisites: In order to apply, students should have successfully completed (received an A or high B in) CH330 during a previous semester at Brown, demonstrated an interest in teaching/mentoring their peers through previous educational/outreach experiences, completed the CH330 interest form, and successfully interviewed for the position with Prof. Rubenstein. Students need not be STEM or chemistry concentrators to be considered, but should be fluent in Chemistry.

Simmons Center Caretaker for the Symbolic Garden of the Enslaved
Simmons Center Caretaker for the Symbolic Garden of the Enslaved
Apply
Job Description:
Overview
The Ruth J. Simmons Center for the Study of Slavery & Justice (Simmons Center) is looking to hire creative and energetic Caretakers for the Symbolic Garden of the Enslaved for the summer (with the potential to continue). The Simmons Center is a scholarly research center with a public humanities mission. Our work is focused on projects and research clusters that examine the history and legacies of the racial slave trade.
In small spaces beside their cabins and huts on the plantation, along marginalized hillsides, in swamps, gullies and forests, and in outdoor sanctuaries created to honor their dead and contemplate that ancestrality, enslaved Africans and their descendants throughout the Americas “stole” back their own time and labor in snatches of the night, on Sundays or “holidays,” to plant garden plots of use, beauty, and spiritual and physical refuge. The Simmons Center's Symbolic Garden of the Enslaved designed by Prof. Geri Augusto draws on that history to render imaginatively a small part of what the slaves knew and wrought, and what they might have thought as they created new landscapes against all odds. It is a work of cognitive justice and contemplation.
Responsibilities
The Caretakers for the Symbolic Garden of the Enslaved will meet regularly (around once per month) with Simmons Center staff to learn about and plan for the physical and intellectual maintenance and growth of the Simmons Center’s Symbolic Garden of the Enslaved and associated programming. During warmer months, work will also include providing physical care for the garden on a regular basis including weeding, planting, watering, painting of the garden wall, and helping with other improvements and general upkeep as assigned. Caretakers will also be involved with creating documentation and both planning and participating in public programming about the garden as a public memorial space on campus.
Qualifications
Strong written and verbal communication skills, very organized and self motivated. Past experience and/or interest in learning about plants and gardening required. Background in Africana Studies/History/Native American and Indigenous Studies/Environmental Studies preferred.
Additional information
This position will begin June 2025 and run through the end of summer (with potential to continue into the academic year). The position is flexible and varied in terms of hours, but we anticipate Caretakers will work around 10-20 hours per month during colder months (for planning meetings and research) and 2-4 additional hours per week during warmer months (for garden maintenance and programming work). We are especially interested in working with students who might be on campus during summer 2025. This position will work in-person at the Center with potential for remote meeting attendance during colder months.
This position is a student worker grade D with a starting salary of $15.65/hr.
Please upload both a resume and cover letter to complete your application.

2025-05-19

Athletics Fitness Supervisor
Athletics Fitness Supervisor
Apply
Job Description:
This position acts as an ambassador of the Division of Athletics and Recreation to the Brown Community which consists of Brown students, faculty, staff, alumni, emeritus, coaches, administrators, RISD students, faculty, staff and the general community population.
Under general supervision, this position assists the Fitness and Wellness Manager in the operation and supervision of the Fitness Loft, Fitness Assistants, studios use and all other spaces where fitness and wellness programming occur. Additionally, they may be assigned various administrative duties within the department.
Job Duties:
Supervises Fitness Assistant position when on shift
Assists with staffing, training and provides performance feedback as needed
Assists with scheduling of staff to provide adequate coverage for the fitness loft, as well as other programs areas and events
Assigns daily work as needed
Completes end of shift report after each shift
Monitors employees’ work to ensure compliance with policies and procedures
Assists in the orientation and training for employees
Assists staff and customers in resolving routine problems and customer issues
Provide 1-2 hours of ‘office hour’ shifts each week to assist with administrative support
Performs other supervisory duties as needed
Administrative:
Provides assistance and/or supervision of operations management to the following areas:
Nelson Fitness Center 
Recreation Management Software
Special Projects and Events
Marketing
Assists with staff scheduling
Assists with equipment management and requests work orders when necessary
Assist with accurate record keeping of all machines and equipment
Miscellaneous:
Assists and performs duties of the staff as needed
Maintains and increases knowledge and skills through attendance at meetings, training and seminars
Performs routine cleaning and maintenance tasks
Assists in the coordination of event set-up and tear down
Performance of additional duties and tasks as assigned
Job Requirements:
Knowledge & experience with exercise physiology and fitness programming preferred.  
Must demonstrate strong leadership, management, and conflict/resolution skills
CPR/AED and First Aid Certification required (or must acquire within 2 months of hire)

2023-06-15

ENGL 1760Z Lead Teaching Fellow, National Education Equity Lab
ENGL 1760Z Lead Teaching Fellow, National Education Equity Lab
Apply
Job Description:
Brown University and the National Education Equity Lab are partnering to offer Brown University college courses to eligible high schools across the country. With your help and support, students from our nation’s most underserved communities can gain access to a rigorous college course and have the opportunity to earn academic college credit while in high school. As a Brown University and National Education Equity Teaching Fellow, you will engage students in synchronous discussions, hold weekly office hours, grade student work, drive student success, and be part of a national community working to advance education equity.
Teaching Fellows (TF) will assist Professor Ravit Reichman with the course ENGL 1760Z  Law and Literature. This course considers how law and literature contribute jointly to our sense of justice and our understanding of injustice. Through novels, poetry, film, legal writings, and legal opinions that have shaped our history, we examine how law and literature are connected to cultural issues like identity, sexuality, injury, policing, and love. Together, we will work to discover connections between how we read, respond to, understand a story or event from the past, and how this understanding generates our sense of justice and our ideas of responsibility. 
JOB DESCRIPTION
A Lead Teaching Fellow is typically an advanced undergraduate or graduate student who teaches in areas in which they have developing expertise from the course structure designed by the faculty instructor.  The Lead Teaching Fellow is required to meet weekly with a co-teacher (teacher from a partner high school depending on the co-teacher schedule), meet weekly with faculty instructor and other teaching fellows, hold weekly online office hours, and teach online weekly to 30-40 high school students. In addition, the Lead Teaching Fellow will have elevated responsibilities including surveying the TF team on a weekly basis and disseminating the results to the instructor. In addition, the Lead TF will be responsible for other administrative duties. For example, attending a selection of discussion sections during the first few weeks of class to ensure curricular consistency; maintaining a communication channel with other TFs to quickly answer questions and/or troubleshoot any teaching or grading issues that may surface; coordinating grades across TFs and ensuring that all supplemental materials for co-teachers and students are maintained and up to date. 
Teaching Fellows may attend the live sessions that are led by a representative from the National Education Equity Lab and a faculty instructor. In addition, they may be asked to provide additional support to the instructor and the students in ways that increase – in quality and quantity – student contact with content experts and, in this way, supports student learning. 
While a Teaching Fellow should be viewed by students as an instructional resource, they are not responsible for creating a syllabus, designing and delivering course content independent of the instructor, or creating individual class modules and lecturers. Teaching Fellows typically work, on average, approximately 15- 18  hours per week.
 Among the tasks a Lead Teaching Fellow is expected to do are:
Surveying teaching team on a weekly basis and providing results to instructor
Attend discussion online discussion sections to ensure curricular consistency

ENGN 0010 Lead Teaching Fellow, National Education Equity Lab
ENGN 0010 Lead Teaching Fellow, National Education Equity Lab
Apply
Job Description:
Brown University and the National Education Equity Lab are partnering to offer Brown University college courses to eligible high schools across the country. With your help and support, students from our nation’s most underserved communities can gain access to a rigorous college course and have the opportunity to earn academic college credit while in high school. As a Brown University and National Education Equity Teaching Fellow, you will engage students in synchronous discussions, hold weekly office hours, grade student work, drive student success, and be part of a national community working to advance education equity.
Teaching Fellows (TF) will assist Professor Karen Haberstroh with the course ENGN 0010 Introduction to Engineering Design, Materials and Structure.      
The purpose of the course is to introduce students to the profession of engineering and the important role engineers play in society, as well as to provide a foundation for further study in engineering. The course begins with the consideration of engineering design and introduces a number of tools that are fundamental to engineering. These may include vectors, computer aided design (CAD), and basic programming (Matlab). Particular attention is then focused on mechanics of materials and the analysis of static structures, but topics also include professional ethics and the social responsibility of engineers
JOB DESCRIPTION
A Lead Teaching Fellow is typically an advanced undergraduate or graduate student who teaches in areas in which they have developing expertise from the course structure designed by the faculty instructor.  The Lead Teaching Fellow is required to meet weekly with a co-teacher (teacher from a partner high school depending on the co-teacher schedule), meet weekly with faculty instructor and other teaching fellows, hold weekly online office hours, and teach online weekly to 30-40 high school students. In addition, the Lead Teaching Fellow will have elevated responsibilities including surveying the TF team on a weekly basis and disseminating the results to the instructor. In addition, the Lead TF will be responsible for other administrative duties. For example, attending a selection of discussion sections during the first few weeks of class to ensure curricular consistency; maintaining a communication channel with other TFs to quickly answer questions and/or troubleshoot any teaching or grading issues that may surface; coordinating grades across TFs and ensuring that all supplemental materials for co-teachers and students are maintained and up to date. 
Teaching Fellows may attend the live sessions that are led by a representative from the National Education Equity Lab and a faculty instructor. In addition, they may be asked to provide additional support to the instructor and the students in ways that increase – in quality and quantity – student contact with content experts and, in this way, supports student learning. 
While a Teaching Fellow should be viewed by students as an instructional resource, they are not responsible for creating a syllabus, designing and delivering course content independent of the instructor, or creating individual class modules and lecturers. Teaching Fellows typically work, on average, approximately 15- 18  hours per week.
 Among the tasks a Lead Teaching Fellow is expected to do are:
Surveying teaching team on a weekly basis and providing results to instructor
Attend discussion online discussion sections to ensure curricular consistency 
Develop and maintain a communication channel with other TFs to answer questions/troubleshoot
Coordinate grades across teaching team
Maintain supplemental co-teaching and student materials 
Teach content as structured and designed by the faculty instructor 
Lead and facilitate 50-60 minute weekly synchronous discussion sections 
Grade and provide students with feedback on homework, exams, tests, written papers, and other assignments
Attend weekly meetings with co-teacher (teacher from a partner high school) depending on co-teaching schedule 
Hold weekly online office hours
Attend weekly meetings with other Teaching Fellows, faculty instructor and representatives from National Education Equity Lab
Tutor students on how to learn (i.e. going over study strategies)
Assist the instructor with administering pre‐instruction and/or post‐instruction 
Provide formative feedback to the instructor regarding student learning
Act as a “liaison” between the instructor and students
COMPENSATION
Lead Teaching Fellows are compensated hourly for the work performed. Lead Teaching Fellows are paid $24.50/hour. All Teaching Fellows are required to submit timesheets for their hours worked. Teaching Fellows are scheduled to work an estimated 15-18 hours per week.
QUALIFICATIONS
Current Brown students (if undergraduate, recommended having senior or junior standing) with expertise in the discipline being taught and with specific content expertise in the special area being taught; 
Prior experience as a teaching assistant or training in pedagogy recommended
PLEASE NOTE:  Since this work involves direct interaction with students who are minors, successful completion of a background check and the Expectations for Working with Minors training is required in order to be hired.

Varsity Center Fueling Station Assistant
Varsity Center Fueling Station Assistant
Apply
Job Description:
The Fueling Station Assistant will assist in managing, monitoring, and stocking both the Varsity Center Fueling Station located in the OMAC Building, as well as a satellite location in the Pizzitola building. Both sites are on the Athletics Campus. The Fueling Station Assistant will be responsible for ensuring all fridges, shelves, and bins are fully stocked with ordered inventory during the open hours of operation.
Essential Duties and Responsibilities:
Manage the operation of the Varsity Center Fueling Station and Pizzitola Fueling Station
Help put away new inventory in the storage cage within the Varsity Center. 
Open and close of the fueling station at the beginning and end of each shift. 
Sweeping, organizing, and keeping the area clean.
Collaborate with the Head of Sports Performance to bring deliveries up to the Varsity Center 1-2x/week.
Assist with creating handouts, labels, social media, and Fueling Station flyers as needed.
Have an interest in Sports Nutrition, and learn basic Sports Nutrition principles to assist with Varsity Athletes in choosing fueling items (Sports Dietitian to help with learning) 
Bring any issues and student athlete requests to the Sports Dietitian.
Must be able to work at least 3 hrs/week.
Ability to work with minimal monitoring and is self-motivated to maintain the Fueling Stations in excellent condition at all times.
Varsity Center Fueling Station Hours of Operation
Monday-Friday from 8:30am-4:00pm (Varsity Center) and Monday-Friday from 1:00-4:00 (Pizzitola)
Fall and Spring Semesters
Closed over the Summer and Winter breaks 
Will operate with Brown University Holiday Schedule and Student Breaks

Athletics Academic Coach Captain
Athletics Academic Coach Captain
Apply
Job Description:
Brown University Athletics is partnered with the Curricular Resource Center for Peer Advising (CRC) who help students engage with Brown's Open Curriculum and effectively utilize its academic resources. The Student-Athlete Development Office will collaborate with CRC's full-time staff, to hire, train and develop academic coaches, to effectively facilitate information sessions, community-building, and individual meetings with student-athletes for advising about the first year experience, independent studies and concentrations, applying for funding opportunities, issues related to the sophomore year, building academic skills and capacity, and more.
Job Description:
Athletics Academic Coach Captain (AACC) will be undergraduate upper-class students (juniors or seniors) or graduate students at Brown who will assist with organizing and executing Athletics Athletics Academic Coach (AAC) regular planning meetings, workshops, and events while assisting with the overall communication of the group.  The AACC will also help undergraduate student-athletes discover their learning styles and develop effective studying strategies for their academic capacity and engagement.  These one-on-one sessions and group-oriented workshops enable student-athletes to:
Develop individualized study habits, test-taking skills, and plans for assignments
Enhance broader academic skills, including time management and effective strategies for preparing for exams
Work on assignments from incomplete courses
Discuss and explore self-care and wellness strategies that will help them stay healthy while they study
Reflect upon their academic goals, personal aspirations, and values as they relate to their academic experience at Brown
Find the appropriate campus resources to enhance their academics and time
Stay motivated and focused on their academic and extracurricular activities
By developing individualized strategies to study effectively and overcome setbacks, we promote resiliency and growth in the classroom and beyond.  
Job Responsibilities/Expectations:
Students with STEM and economics backgrounds are especially encouraged to apply, though we are interested in students with any academic background.  AACC are responsible for four main areas:
Conducting regular AAC support meetings as well as plan and execute multi-team workshops and events as assigned by the Student-Athlete Senior Manager.
Monitor and reply to the AAC communication platform for support purposes and assist with overall communication to AACs. 
Scheduling and conducting individual appointments with high-risk student-athletes on their team(s) to assess their personal study habits and to improve their learning approaches. AACCs typically work with no more than 1-2 athletic teams a semester and meet as an AAC group once a week or once every two weeks.
Facilitate a monthly workshop for student-athletes on their team(s) throughout the semester on topics such as reading strategies, taking notes, test preparation, and time management.
Hold individual and group drop-in/open-hour sessions for student-athletes on their team(s) interested in support during the midterm and finals periods.
AACCs must participate in pre-semester training (Fall/Spring), bi/weekly team meetings, and evaluation. AACCs can expect to hold evening and weekend hours conducting workshops or individual student-athlete consultations. Other expectations include:
Interest in taking on a leadership role within Student-Athlete Development programming. 
Demonstrated ability to lead a group of peers to accomplish a common goal.
Demonstrated interest in the Athletics and Recreation and Curricular Resource Center’s mission statement and goals.
Prior experience advising student-athletes about academic opportunities and resources.
Prior experience working within communities of color and with students from under-represented/minoritized communities.
Motivated and energetic; friendly, patient, and approachable.
Ability to work independently and collaboratively on various tasks/projects in an office setting.
Attention to detail and ability to follow through on a project from start to finish.
Capable of planning events and public speaking.
Excellent written communication skills.
Violations of the Academic Code or Student Code of Conduct will result in removal as an academic coach/captain.
Compensation: $19/hr
Recruiting Start Date:
2025-04-08

Athletics Tutor Captain
Athletics Tutor Captain
Apply
Job Description:
Brown University Athletics is seeking  juniors and seniors to provide tutoring services to student-athletes as well as help with the overall leadership of the tutor cohort.
The primary responsibilities of the Athletics Tutor Captain is to assist with organizing and executing regular tutor planning meetings, professional development workshops, and events while assisting with the overall communication of the group.  In addition, a Tutor Captain will assist student-athletes to become independent learners, persist in college, and reach their academic goals. 
Tutor Captains will provide regularly scheduled individual/group/drop-in tutoring sessions to clarify and review concepts taught in class, explain processes and promote the use of appropriate study strategies. Tutoring supports classroom-centered activities, and as such, the emphasis and content of the tutoring sessions is determined by the student-athlete's needs. Tutors will be able to build their own schedule with their student-athletes, according to need and availability. High-need subject areas: APMA, BIOL, CHEM, ECON, ENGN, MATH PHYS.
Requirements:
Experience as an Athletics or Sheridan Center tutor for at least one semester.
Assist with planning and execute all tutor meetings, professional development activities and mandatory training sessions
Assist with overall communication to tutors
Completed relevant course with a B or higher
Must be in good academic standing
Effective time management and communication skills
Organizational skills and punctuality
Recognize different learning styles and student preferences
Create a professional and welcoming environment by modeling respect for students’ diverse cultures, language skills, and experiences
Use active listening strategies to allow student to determine content and pace of tutoring
Utilize listening and questioning strategies as the primary tutoring method to diagnose student needs and monitor progress 
Utilize feedback and reflection to improve practice 
Recognize primary role to help students become more confident, more successful, self directed learners 
Make appropriate referrals to other campus and community resources as needed
Able to work a minimum of 5 hours per week
Please keep in mind that tutor/captains are matched with tutees based on need and request of courses. If hired, tutor/captains will be contacted when their courses are needed.  Violations of the Academic Code or Student Code of Conduct will result in removal as a tutor/captain.
Compensation: $19/hr

Graduate Fellowship Advisor
Graduate Fellowship Advisor
Apply
Job Description:
Remote Opportunity
Graduate Fellowship Advisors support sophomores, juniors, seniors, and recent alumni in the development of their application materials for select national and international fellowships. Liaising with the Assistant Dean of Fellowships and Assistant Director of Fellowships, advisors provide supportive, structured feedback for students through pre-application and post-application support as well as writing workshops. Additionally, advisors may serve on select campus review committees, reading and assessing student applications, supporting the preparation of institutional letters of endorsement, and helping students practice for upcoming finalist interviews.
The Fellowship Program pursues advising practices that emphasize student learning and self-exploration, offering guidance and writing support that invites students to notice, cultivate, and effectively articulate their curiosities and goals.
Core Duties:
Works directly with students to inform them about fellowship opportunities, mentor them as they explore opportunities, and help them to consider these opportunities within the broader framework of their educational and personal goals.
Advise students on their application materials directly in one-on-one meetings or in application workshops. Provide direct feedback about their written work and overall portfolio in the application process.
Prepare and oversee the preparation of institutional letters of endorsement, as required by specific fellowships.
Primary Responsibilities: 
Pre-application support: Advisors work closely with 20-25 students to explore a select fellowship opportunity, assess eligibility, and develop application materials. Advisors are expected to hold at least two and no more than three 30-minute advising sessions with each student. In addition, advisors support on-campus writing workshops for select fellowships.
Review Committee: Advisors read 10-15 student fellowship applications for select campus review committees. For each student application, advisors complete a short form assessing the candidate's overall strengths for the given opportunity. The advisor then takes part in a committee meeting to discuss applicant feedback and meets with the student to relay the feedback.
Post-application support: Advisors provide each student with one 30-minute advising session to discuss the outcome of the review process. For non-nominated students, this session entails debriefing on their application and identifying further fellowship and experiential learning opportunities to explore. For nominated students, this session entails discussing feedback to strengthen, finalize, and submit their application.
Mock interview committee: Advisors serve on a rolling mock interview committee that convenes to support students invited to interview for select fellowship opportunities. Mock interviews take place in October and November, with each interview lasting 1 hour. Advisors are expected to develop interview questions that center the applicant’s work, personality, and goals as well as realistically simulate experience of that specific opportunity (e.g., behavioral interview questions or position/stance questions). Typically, 10-15 mock interviews are convened each year for the fellowships supported by advisors.
Institutional letters of endorsement: Advisors prepare draft letters of endorsement for select fellowship opportunities.
Time Commitment: 
Anticipated for 320 total hours (approximately 10-20 hours a week for 4-6 months), beginning as early as June 1 and ending as late as November 30.
Duration:
Anticipated 4-6 months – beginning as early as June 1 and ending as late as November 30.
Rate:  This is a paid position at $23.00/hr. for any work taken on beyond the graduate school primary appointment, as per GLO guidelines.
Job Competencies:
Strong proficiency in written and verbal communication, with demonstrated ability to communicate effectively across multiple audiences.
Skillful judgment and discretion in handling FERPA-protected and confidential materials.
Ability to meet necessary deadlines and manage multiple time-sensitive processes.
Demonstrated ability to support a community of diverse perspectives and cultures in an inclusive environment, as well as demonstrated success in collaborative work with diverse faculty, students, and staff.
Demonstrated experience advocating for and making change toward goals for diversity, inclusion, and equity while supporting students from historically underrepresented and/or minoritized backgrounds. (Note: All Fellowships Advisors are required to undergo anti-bias training as well as read provided materials before advising students. We want to ensure that all students of all backgrounds and identities feel welcome and supported when meeting with advisors.)
Experience working with students, effective presentation skills, and experience in or working knowledge of select national and/or international fellowships application processes preferred.
Eligibility:
Must be a PhD student, PhD candidates beyond their third year of graduate study preferred
If on full summer stipend, employment conditional on submission and receipt of a request for exemption from the 12-hour limit (see Activities Outside of Stipended Appointments for more information)
For more information, please contact: fellowships@brown.edu

Presidential Scholars Program Content Area Peer Counselor
Presidential Scholars Program Content Area Peer Counselor
Apply
Job Description:
Content Area Peer Counselors are PSP-specific positions for upperclassmen with expertise in academic courses, departments, concentration requirements, and research. These students will function to support students exploring departments in both challenging introductory coursework and navigating the department. As PSP scholars, CAPCs are familiar with the process of finding research experiences and talking with PIs in their content area. This will help underclassmen navigate the unique culture of each department as they search for research practicums. CAPCs will also support students through challenging introductory courses.

CAPCs will be responsible for:
Supporting students with core academic and study skills
Helping students create study plans during midterm and final exams
Reviewing core content and facilitating peer study groups
Helping students with course selection
Advising students on the options for research in their given content area
Supporting students with meeting faculty and looking for research and shadowing opportunities

Job Description:
Mathematics Grader
Time Commitment: The successful applicant must be able to commit 3-4 hours per week to their position for the full length of the term (14 weeks). Additional hours must be approved in advance by the Course Head and Coordinator of Student Affairs and may be considered depending on the class enrollment and responsibility of the UTA. 
Responsibilities: The successful applicant will be responsible for grading homework assignments in alignment with the rubric and guidance from the Course Head. Homework should be graded with the grades recorded in a manner that is timely, as communicated by the Course Head. Graders are expected to conduct themselves professionally when interacting with any student in the course, as well as the rest of the teaching team, and should raise any issues of concern related to the course to the Course Head.
The successful applicant must complete the I-9 processes prior to their first day of work. Graders are responsible for keeping track of their hours worked, including any course-related meetings and training, and recording them in Workday within the week worked. 
Qualifications: The department is seeking applicants that have completed their first year of study and are considering concentrating in a STEM discipline, preferably Mathematics or Applied Mathematics. Applicants should be able to demonstrate a high level of confidence with the concepts covered in the course(s) applied for, typically by having performed well in the course themselves, and evidence of pursuit of mathematics beyond the course is preferred. In addition to mathematics knowledge, the candidate should have strong time management and communication skills.

Job Description:
Time Commitment: The successful applicant must be able to commit 6 hours per week to their position for the full length of the term (14 weeks). Additional hours must be approved in advance by the Course Head and Coordinator of Student Affairs and may be considered depending on the class enrollment and responsibility of the UTA.

Attend meetings with Course Head and/or occasional lecture sections;
Facilitate one-hour weekly recitation sections of 30 students;
Grade and return homework in a timely manner (to be determined in consultation with the Course Head);
Holding office hours;
Administering and grading quizzes;
Provide feedback to the Course Head based on student observations and/or interactions.
Undergraduate TAs are expected to conduct themselves professionally when interacting with any student in the course, as well as the rest of the teaching team. 
Prior to beginning a UTA position, the successful applicant must complete the I-9 processes and participate in the Sheridan Center Undergraduate TA orientation. Student Accessibility Services (SAS) Technology Support
Student Accessibility Services (SAS) Technology Support
Apply
Job Description:
Position Overview: The SAS Technology Support is a key support role within the Student Accessibility Services office. This position will be responsible for back end support and updating of SAS information technology and databases. Selected candidates will be responsible for developing and implementing database updates and maintaining internal SAS information systems. 
Primary Responsibilities: 
The primary responsibility of this position will be to maintain and update current SAS information spreadsheets and update the necessary code. The candidate will also aid in the development of new database solutions and improving current code and database structure. 
Job Requirements - Knowledge, Skills, and Abilities: 
Detail-oriented with an ability to troubleshoot and manage multiple projects. 
Proficiency in Google applications (Google Sheets, Gmail), and basic computer skills (scanning, uploading, downloading, saving files). 
Proficiency in Windows, MacOS, AndroidOS, and iOS 
Strong background in Adobe Suite, database management, and web development Knowledge of XML a plus 
Understanding and handling of confidential information with discretion. 
Reliability and good academic and judicial standing. 
Commitment to diversity and understanding of disability as a form of diversity. Ability to work independently and collaboratively in a team setting. 
Availability for cross training in different areas of the SAS office team 
Capable of lifting up to 30 pounds and transporting equipment across the campus as needed/scheduled Availability: 
This position is Hybrid primarily remote with regular scheduled time in the office. While there is some flexibility, a consistent schedule is preferred. 
Availability for training as soon as possible. Availability to work morning and/or afternoon shifts Commitment for the current academic year is important.
Hours: 
Approximately 5-10 hours per week. With the possibility of additional hours during peak times. For all inquiries please contact sas-exams@brown.edu
