Undergraduate Research Assistant in Education Policy Research – Dr. Matt Kraft 2025
Undergraduate Research Assistant in Education Policy Research – Dr. Matt Kraft 2025
Apply
Job Description:
Undergraduate Research Assistant in Education Policy Research – Dr. Matt Kraft
Dr. Matthew Kraft, Associate Professor of Education and Economics, is seeking part-time research assistants to collaborate with him on one or more of several ongoing research projects over the academic year.  Prof. Kraft’s research interests include the economics of education, the impact of climate change on education systems, education policy analysis, and applied quantitative methods for causal inference. His primary work focuses on policies to improve educator and organizational effectiveness in K-12 urban public schools. He runs a large and vibrant research lab.
The RA will assist in coding, data collection, data analysis, data cleaning, literature reviews, and other research tasks. Anticipated 8-10 hours of work per week.
The part-time position is open to undergraduates and graduate students.
Historically underrepresented students are strongly encourage to apply.  No prior experience is necessary although a demonstrated interest in education policy analysis is important. Applicants must have the ability to work independently and be self-directed. Prior coursework in statistics/quantitative methods and strong writing and editing skills are a plus.
Application Instructions: Please complete the application process in Workday and submit in Workday 1) a cover letter 2) a resume, and 3) a writing sample of any length. The cover letter should include an explanation of the candidate’s interest in the position as well as a summary of his/her relevant qualifications and experience.  Applications will be accepted until the position is filled.

2025-02-25

Joukowsky Institute Research Apprentice (Spring 2025)
Joukowsky Institute Research Apprentice (Spring 2025)
Apply
Job Description:
**Students must be Archaeology concentrators in order to be considered for this position.**
Additional information about apprenticeships and the application process is available at: https://archaeology.brown.edu/academics/undergraduate/research-opportunities/research-apprenticeship-program-archaeology
The Joukowsky Institute for Archaeology is again calling for applications from Archaeology concentrators only for this semester’s Research Apprenticeship Program in Archaeology.  Applications should propose collaborative research projects with Institute faculty (including visiting faculty and postdoctoral fellows). Through the apprenticeship program, individual students work directly with a Joukowsky Institute faculty member on faculty research.  We offer this program each semester.

It is expected that students will not devote more than approximately 3-4 hours per week, averaged over the semester, to this apprenticeship.  Applications must be submitted jointly by both the student and the JIAAW faculty member with whom the student plans to work -- as an email message sent by the student to Sarah Sharpe with the faculty member cc'ed for their approval.

Additional details on the program, including the application process, are on our website.  Note that the first step in the application process is to talk with a faculty member about potential apprenticeships, and that all applications must be approved in writing by the faculty member with whom the student intends to work.

Fall 2025 Head Teaching Assistant (HTA) - Computer Science
Fall 2025 Head Teaching Assistant (HTA) - Computer Science
Apply
Job Description:
Job Description: A Head TA (HTA) works with the instructor to coordinate all aspects of a course during a given semester, including management of the course’s UTAs. HTAs are hired each mid-semester for the following semester's courses. The course instructor conducts the interviews (perhaps with the assistance of the previous semester’s HTAs) and submits preferences to the meta-TAs, who coordinate the hiring process. The TA program page includes additional information about TA program hiring. The work of an HTA is supervised by the course instructor and perhaps by a PhD graduate student TA. 
Responsibilities: The nature of the tasks may vary depending on the teaching needs of the individual course. During the academic semester, duties may include:
Coordinating the work of the course UTAs for tasks such as office hours, running sections, responding to discussion board posts, and grading assignments or exams
Serving as a communication link between UTAs and the course instructor
Responding to TA coordination requests from the MTAs
Coordinating with course STAs as needed to release assignments (if applicable)
Planning the course’s TA camp schedule in conjunction with the instructor
Planning and running staff meetings, perhaps with assistance from the instructor
Assigning students to sections or labs (if applicable)
Creating scripts to assist with course administration tasks
Maintaining internal information resources, such as student attendance at sections or labs, entering instructor-approved extensions into grading tools, or tracking late days
Proofreading assignment handouts, exams, and other materials prior to release to students
Updating information resources to release assignments, notes, and other materials
Administering grading processes, including releasing rubrics, working with the instructor to answer questions about how to grade assignments, making sure UTAs complete grading on time, and releasing grades to students
Holding TA/office hours
Responding to discussion board posts
Grading programs and written assignments (including exams)
Updating assignment handouts, solutions, autograders, grading rubrics, course documents, or course websites
Attending class to help answer questions or support instructional activities
Head TAs may not grant extensions or handle Dean’s Notes or Accommodations letters. HTAs may not be solely responsible for development of assignments, course materials, or grading rubrics, though they may contribute to developing these with oversight and feedback from the course instructor.
During TA Camp (the week prior to the start of the semester) and by agreement during the academic year or during the break before the semester starts, HTAs typically assist with more extensive course development, with duties that may include:
Drafting new assignment ideas or handouts
Writing solutions for new or revised assignments
Writing test suites or other autograder configuration for new or revised assignments
Preparing support code, sample code or demos of programs
Developing new software infrastructure
Designing new approaches to organizing office hours, grading, and other tasks that involve extensive staff time
Expectations for extensive course development for individual courses are listed in the hiring blurbs for each course, which are linked to the TA program page prior to HTA applications opening for each semester. All jobs are subject to the terms agreed to by Brown University and TALO.
Recruiting Start Date:
2025-01-31

Fall 2025 Undergraduate Teaching Assistant (UTA) - Computer Science
Fall 2025 Undergraduate Teaching Assistant (UTA) - Computer Science
Apply
Job Description:
Job Description: An Undergraduate Teaching Assistant (UTA) assists the instructor both inside and outside the classroom on activities related to the teaching of a particular course. Criteria are set by the instructors of each course. UTAs are hired each semester (between mid-semester and reading period) for the following semester's courses. The course instructor, course head TAs (HTAs), and graduate TAs (if the course has them) conduct the interviews and submit preferences to the meta-TAs, who coordinate the hiring process along with the Directors of Undergraduate Studies. The TA program page includes additional information about TA program hiring. The work of a UTA is supervised by the instructor directly and indirectly through an HTA or PhD graduate student TA. 
Responsibilities: The nature of the tasks may vary depending on the teaching needs of the individual course. During the academic semester, duties may include:
Holding TA/office hours
Responding to discussion board posts
Grading programs and written assignments (including exams)
Running (and recording attendance at) weekly lab, discussion, or other small-group sections 
Reviewing handouts and documents for clarity, completeness and accuracy
Updating assignment handouts, solutions, autograders, grading rubrics, course documents, or course websites
Attending class to help answer questions or support instructional activities
Mentoring students about the course and CS in general
During TA Camp (the week prior to the start of the semester) and by agreement during the academic year or during the break before the semester starts, UTAs may assist with more extensive course development, with duties that may include:
Drafting new assignment ideas or handouts
Writing solutions for new or revised assignments
Writing test suites or other autograder configuration for new or revised assignments
Preparing support code, sample code or demos of programs
Developing new software infrastructure
Expectations for extensive course development for individual courses are listed in the hiring blurbs for each course, which are linked to the UTA program page prior to UTA applications

Alumni Relations Reunion Event Staff
Alumni Relations Reunion Event Staff
Apply
Job Description:
The Alumni Relations Office Events Team is looking to hire students for various positions for Reunion Weekend, May 23-25, 2025 including Bellhops, Event Staff, Concierge Staff, Class Staff, Headquarter Staff, and Registration Staff.
Responsibilities:
Student staffers will be responsible for greeting returning alumni to campus and providing event support assistance to returning alumni throughout Reunion/Commencement Weekend. Students will be responsible for various tasks including, but not limited to:
Setting up and breaking down events
Answering questions and troubleshooting event issues
Entertaining alumni children 
Greeting and mingling with alumni guests and assisting alumni with luggage and transportation needs
Required Skills:
We are looking for candidates who have proven skills, including:
Ability to take initiative, multi-task, remain flexible, think quickly on their feet, and thrive in a continuously changing environment
Enjoy engaging alumni in light conversation
Ability to work long shifts (see below)
Required to possess a never-ending optimistic attitude, show up for shifts promptly and pitch in to help regardless of the situation
Prior experience working Reunion Weekend a plus
Ability to lift over 25 lbs.
If you are interested in being a BellHop and can lift over 25 lbs. Please indicate this in your responses
Compensation:
Positions pay $15.50 per hour and require attendance at mandatory paid training sessions May 21 and 22 and long hours of mandatory shifts May 23 and 24 (with a potential 5 hour-shift on May 25).
IMPORTANT NOTE! Student Staff will work long hours (8-12 hours per day) on May 23 and 24 (and possibly shorter shift 25), based on specific assignments.
Shifts during Reunion Weekend will be long and may begin before 7AM and may end after midnight on Friday and Saturday. The position includes complimentary extended housing until May 25 and complimentary meals during Reunion Weekend.

2025-01-29

ENGN 0900 - UTA - Chaltas
ENGN 0900 - UTA - Chaltas
Apply
Job Description:
As a TA for ENGN 0900, you are expected to:
• Prepare for weekly sections by re-reading cases, reviewing TA discussion guides, and the your own notes from your time as a student in the class.
• Hold weekly section meetings to discuss the section cases, encouraging all students to actively participate. Meet with students outside section meetings to make up missed sections.
• In the event that a section is not held in a week, make up the case discussion on another day.
• Support students throughout the semester, enabling them to enjoy the learning process. Set up time to meet with students who cannot make section.
• Grade ~50 section papers per semester following provided rubric (specific number TBD pending both course enrollment and number of TAs).
• Compile section participation grades (following provided rubric) and send to head TAs and Professor Chaltas at end of semester (mid-May for ENGN 0900). Specific due date will be provided.
• Communicate weekly with students in section, as the first line in making sure they’re comprehending material and staying on track.
• Proactively share any insights or issues regarding individual students or the course overall or with the head TAs and Professor Chaltas.
Attend monthly TA Meetings
 Position Qualifications
Must have taken ENGN 900 in the past.Past TA experience for ENGN 90 or 900 also a plus. 
This position is from January 10, 2025 through May 31, 2025, working 2.5 hours per week.

2025-01-09

Events & Operations Intern - Taubman Center
Events & Operations Intern - Taubman Center
Apply
Job Description:
The Taubman Center for American Politics and Policy seeks a student assistant for
events and operations. The primary purpose of the position is to provide assistance to
the Center’s Program Manager on pre-event logistics and other administrative tasks:
Job Requirements:
● Event planning and on-site execution of events, including set-up and event strike
● Set-up, and management of reception spaces, performance areas, and other
activated event areas
● Corresponding with vendors, performers, and affiliates
● Providing post-event input and analysis
Qualifications:
● Must be available to work evenings 5PM-7:30PM (Monday-Thursday)
● Experience in event operations is highly desirable
● Impeccable oral and written communication skills and ability to excel at
multitasking, working under deadlines, and paying attention to detail
● Excellent internet research skills
● Mastery of the major social media platforms including Facebook, Instagram,
Twitter, and LinkedIn
● Be a self-motivated, confident manager, and capable delegator
The events intern will be supervised by Othniel Harris, Program Manager for the
Taubman Center.
We envision the position to provide 5 hours of work per week, plus some additional
hours for event work.
To apply: Candidates should submit a current resume and a short statement (150 words
max) outlining relevant experience in events and outreach along with their application in
Workday.

2025-01-06

Student Accessibility Services Graduate Proctor
Student Accessibility Services Graduate Proctor
Apply
Job Description:
Student Accessibility Services (SAS) is seeking Graduate students for proctoring exams with accommodations, this may include reading and scribing when needed.
Section 1: Major Responsibilities
SAS Graduate student proctors will monitor students with accommodations during exams and confidently troubleshoot as needed. SAS Graduate proctors will be in communication with faculty of the course. 
The role of a proctor may also involve reading exam questions to students or scribing answers as dictated by a student. Advance notice and instruction will be given to the proctor.
Other duties include the pick-up/ drop-off of exam materials to the Instructor/Department. As well as typically picking up and dropping off student exam laptops at SAS.
Section 2: Time Commitment
Hours are generally during weekday hours, but vary depending on the number of requests and time of the semester. FInal exams include weekend days. 
Please note students must be eligible to work in the USA and a Form I-9 must be completed at the HR Service Center before being officially hired.
Section 3: Required Availability
SAS Graduate Proctors are needed throughout the semester, especially during peak times in the semester, midterms and finals.
Section 4: Job Qualifications and Skills
Job Qualifications
Applicants need to be punctual, have excellent communication skills, and maintain a high level of confidentiality with student information and commitment to the integrity of exams. 
Each SAS graduate proctor will need to sign a FERPA form at the time of hire.
At hire, SAS proctors will review and sign the SAS proctor guidelines
Skills
Great time management skills 
Effective written and verbal communication skills 
Ability to work independently and efficiently 
Detail oriented 

All questions should be directed to: sas-exams@brown.edu or  jennifer_agudelo@brown.edu

Burns- Research Assistant (Remote)
Burns- Research Assistant (Remote)
Apply
Job Description:
This position will assist a PhD student with data collection and management for their dissertation. The dissertation project examines how states determine functional and medical eligibility for Medicaid Long-Term Care, and how different characteristics of states’ eligibility algorithms are associated with racial inequality in access to Medicaid Long-Term Care.
The primary role of this position will be to coordinate data collection on each state’s eligibility decision-making process. There is also a possibility of assisting with other parts of the project depending on the research assistant’s interest. For example, the research assistant could sit in on interviews with Medicaid stakeholders or help with data cleaning in Stata or R.

Attention to detail and willingness to learn are the most important requirements for this position. The research assistant must be available for weekly meetings either over Zoom or in-person.

Job Description:
The Advancement Marketing team seeks motivated student interns to provide logistical and administrative support for its various goals, projects, and other department initiatives to promote, solicit and thank alumni, parents, and friends for their philanthropic support of current students at Brown. Student interns report to the Assistant Director of Project Operations - Advancement Marketing, and will gain invaluable experience across a wide array of direct marketing mediums, including but not limited to: 
Social media
Email
Direct mail
Peer-to-peer texting
Additionally, student interns will assist the Advancement Marketing team with student engagement, data collection, research, user-generated content, and content sourcing.

Experience with Excel, Google sheets, Google Docs, Word, and social media platforms.

Experience with Adobe Creative Suite-with a particular interest in audio and video editing. 
Excellent writing skills in creating marketing content (videos, quotes, images) that are available for sharing in promotion, solicitation, and stewardship marketing campaigns.
HTML experience is a plus.
Work Hours

Reunion Student Staff Leader
Reunion Student Staff Leader
Apply
Job Description:
ABOUT THIS ROLE:
The Alumni Relations Office Events Team is looking to hire students as members of the Leadership Team for Alumni Reunion Weekend. The Leadership Team plays an important role in the execution of all aspects of Alumni Reunion Weekend. In this role, Leaders work as both a team and individually to adequately train, manage and direct assigned groups of the 80 plus student staff members. The Leadership Team serves as the liaisons between student staff, the Student Staff Director and the Alumni Relations Department staff; in this role they ensure that all student staff have sufficient knowledge and are adequately prepared to carry out the many tasks involved in creating enjoyable experiences for Brown alumni during Reunion Weekend. Professional attire throughout much of Reunion Weekend is necessary and/or required.
QUALIFICATIONS:
Members of the Leadership team need to maintain a sincere interest in the success of their staff and are not afraid to roll up their sleeves to assist in the accomplishment of a goal or task. They should have a positive and cheerful attitude regardless of the situation and be ready to assist and participate in all the Reunion preparations and continue with this attitude and self-motivation throughout Reunion Weekend. There are a variety of leadership positions leading our student staff in the roles of student bellhops, the support of multicultural and reunion class events, registration and concierge to name a few.
We seek candidates who have proven leadership and/or event skills that have been tested on campus and elsewhere. They have experience leading peers, motivating peers to work to the best of their abilities, and mediating peer disputes. In addition, they will have the ability to take initiative, pay attention to detail, multi-task, remain flexible, think quickly on their feet, and troubleshoot. They have the ability to work as part of a team and independently, possess a delightful personality and enjoy the experience of being a Brown undergrad. It will be necessary for the candidates to have the ability to accomplish goals on deadline, communicate clearly, take direction, delegate tasks and seamlessly manage the many changing needs of a large group. Candidates should have prior experience with peer mentoring and coaching, participating and leading team building exercises, mediating conflict among peers, and giving PowerPoint presentations to large groups.
IMPORTANT SCHEDULING NOTE: 
Leaders will spend time organizing staff schedules, preparing for student staff training sessions, and assisting with general Reunion preparations the weekend prior to and week leading up to Reunion Weekend (after finals period- May 17-22, 2025).   
All members of the Leadership Team will work long hours (10-15 hours per day) during Reunion Weekend -- May 23, 24, and 25, 2025. Please note that shifts during Reunion Weekend will be long and may begin before 7 am and may end well after midnight based on specific leadership roles. 
COMPENSATION & INCENTIVES: 
This position pays $18.00 per hour and requires several orientations and team building sessions with all members of the leadership team throughout the spring semester. Leadership Team members are also required to attend (and in some cases lead) training sessions (May 20, 21, & 22). All orientation and training sessions are paid. All members of the Leadership Team will need to commit to work through 5pm on May 25. Position includes complimentary extended housing until May 26 and complimentary meals during Reunion Weekend itself.  We will be hiring between 10 - 12 student staff leaders.
INTERVIEW SCHEDULE: 
Round one interviews will be conducted via Zoom between January 15–January 29 (not including weekends). Round two interviews for finalists will be scheduled on campus between February 12 – February 26 (not including weekends).
Recruiting Start Date:
2024-12-03

ENGN 0900 - STA/PRIME TA
ENGN 0900 - STA/PRIME TA
Apply
Job Description:
We have two distinct roles for ENGN 0900 STAs during the semester. See below. Note that All STAs will grade questions on the final exam between exam when exam is offered and late May with focus on mid-May

1) Working with Prof. Chaltas to identify an HBS case for final exam and write the final exam. This represents a deep dive into the case and working with Prof. Chaltas to write a final exam (and develop answer key) based on past finals.
2) Managing Class Participation & Attendance : STAs attend class and track student participation. They also track comments in Canvas discussions and track attendance taken via Tophat technology platform. Must be able to attend class (Tues/Thus 10:30-11:50AM in BH 166)

Students will likely work less than 5 hours per week during the semester, but the final exam grading takes place during and just after exam period does take additional time. 
 Position Qualifications:
Knowledge of core management principles. Experience with case method approach to teaching. Excellent written and spoken English language skills
This position is from January 20, 2025 through May 31, 2025, working five hours weekly.
